Review_body: Let's put this bluntly: THE RAID kicks ass. If you're a fan of martial arts movies where two skilled men beat the hell out of each other for an eternity, then this is the film for you. However, if you value dense and complex plotting, method actors working through depths of emotion with subtlety and skill and a sublime and intellectual subject matter, then you'd better bypass this one. THE RAID is all about action, action, and more action.The first thing that becomes apparent is this film's low budget. Ostensibly set in a tower block, in reality the whole of the film takes place in just a few corridors and rooms within that place. There isn't a huge cast, either, so the tagline '30 floors of chaos' is a bit of a cheat, as 27 or so of those floors are entirely superfluous (besides, when they show the tower block at the beginning it looks to be about 15 stories high rather than 30). Nevertheless, Welsh director Gareth Evans knows just the way to get the most of out his sets and budgets, utilising props, set dressing and imaginative segues from one scene to the next in order to convince you otherwise.The storyline is very slim indeed, and barely worth scribbling on the back of a beer mat. Character motivations are slim and even the hero barely gets a look in in terms of back story and drive. Tony Jaa's WARRIOR KING looks like a masterpiece of complicated storytelling and nuanced acting in comparison to this. But I haven't mentioned the action yet, and that's where the film really excels.The fight scenes are exhaustive, exhilarating and completely fascinating. Evans makes use of hyper-kinetic camera-work to weave in and around his opponents with just the right level of speed and sophistication to allow his audiences to feel every kick and punch. The actors are exceptionally skilled; Uwais has the chance to become an action superstar in his own right if he keeps up with what he achieves here, although the real star of the movie is Yayan Ruhian as the villainous henchman, Mad Dog. Ruhian is a beast, a tiny top fighter who seems virtually unbeatable as the film progresses. Lashings of violent death, some explosive shoot-outs and ingenious methods of destruction and one great CGI set-piece involving a stairwell later, plus an extended fight scene at the climax which just gets better and better.This is a draining experience, up there with the best that the martial arts genre has to offer. It's even better on repeat viewing, and it might, just might, serve as the launching point for at least three new careers in action cinema (Evans, Uwais and Ruhian). If, like me, you've seen so many action flicks that you're getting slightly bored with them, check this out and be left reeling by a real powerhouse punch to the gut.

Review title: Good action, loses realism near the end
Review_body: It's Jakarta, Indonesia, and Lieutenant Wahyu invades drug lord Tama's hideout. The SWAT team becomes trapped in the highrise apartment with no backup. Lt. Wahyu hasn't informed his superiors about the operation. Now they must fight their way out all by themselves.This is an eye opening Indonesian action movie. It is expertly made, and superior to most Hollywood fare. The first hour is a no non-sense, serious action, not about pretty boys ab-offs. But the last 40 minutes does turn into kung-fu fighting unrealistic action. The tension is built thru realistic action scenes. There isn't much explaining needed. But the last 40 minutes do devolve into too much hand to hand kung fu fighting. Other than that, this is a serious action movie. A great serious watch.

My knowledge of Indonesian cinema is somewhere between zero and zero. So when I heard about the excitement about an Indonesian martial arts thriller called The Raid, I felt I needed to check it out.Its no secret that Hollywood action films have been stuck in a recent rut. They have relied on the same ageing bunch of actors making increasingly inferior films with tired scripts.The Raid owes a debt to Die Hard as the action takes place in a tower block. A SWAT team are out to capture a crime lord and two of his most trusted man, the brutal Mad Dog and Andi located on the 15th floor.The SWAT team includes a rookie, Rama (Iko Uwais) a devout Muslim with a young wife, heavily pregnant. The team is led by Sergeant Jaka and supervised by a shifty Lieutenant.However the team are soon trapped as the raid is discovered and the hordes of bad guys start to pick off the SWAT team members until there are only a few left. Its Rama with his fighting skills that helps the others to survive but it seems he is getting help from an unlikely source and the remaining SWAT team members without help need to break out from the block to escape.The version I watched is subtitled, the storyline is basic and functional. What is important is the unrelenting action and breathtaking choreography which is obviously inspired by Hong Kong martial arts cinema.The film was directed by a Welshman, Gareth Huw Evans who is certainly a talent worth following. The Raid certainly deserves your time.

Review title: Violent, Full of Action and without Story
Review_body: In Jakarta, Indonesia, Lieutenant Wahyu (Pierre Gruno) organizes the invasion of an apartment building that is the safe house of the powerful and cruel drug lord Tama (Ray Sahetapy) and his gang. The SWAT team breaks in the building but one lookout sees and warns the gangsters and the police force is trapped on the seventh floor. They learn that Lt. Wahyu has not informed his superiors about the operation. Now the police officers have to fight with limited ammunition against the armed and dangerous gangsters. "Serbuan Maut" is a violent and full of action movie unfortunately without story. Actually it seems to be a video game, with police officers and gangster using different weapons and fight. I found it overrated in IMDb. My vote is six.Title (Brazil): "Operação Invasão" ("Operation Invasion")

I did watch Merantau a while ago, but I wasn't quite fond of that I have to admit. Not the action scenes in it, but the story/drama wasn't really what I hoped for. Of course as it seems, this was just a training ground (I'll call it that) for making this movie. And "The Raid" is just fantastic! Not that big of a story there of course (actually the title describes what you will see, nothing more, nothing less), but the way the action is shot? Absolutely amazing! A must see.Of course you have to like action movies for that to be true. If you are not that much into them, than don't bother. America took notice and a remake will be on the way (though it won't happen until 2014, so go ahead and watch this before that). I cannot recommend this high enough, something the Empire Magazine does too: It rated the movie with 5 stars (which is a rare rating and is only given to a few movies) ...

I saw the trailer for this Indonesian film at the time of its release and it looked really cool and exciting, and I was really lucky to be able to see it before it was available to most of the public, I just hoped it would live up to the good rating the critics gave it. Basically a derelict apartment building, fifteen stories high, in the heart of the slums, serves as a safe house for some of the most dangerous criminals in Jakarta, it is considered impregnable and untouchable by rivals of the crime lord Tama Riyadi (Ray Sahetapy) and even the police, but an elite SWAT team have been tasked with storming the block and taking the mobster down. Expectant father and rookie cop Rama (Iko Uwais) is part of the twenty man team raiding the building, with Sergeant Jaka (Joe Taslim) leading and Lieutenant Wahyu (Pierre Gruno) guiding them, and to get inside they have one of the local residents, who is returning with medicine for his sick wife, help them out, and other residents along the way are silenced and tied up to stop detection. It is when the team reach the sixth floor however that a young lookout spots them and raises the alarm to the criminals that the police are inside, before he is shot and killed, and Tama calls for reinforcements, while two snipers take the two officers outside on the ground floor trapping the team inside, and slowly of the SWAT team members are killed in the growing chaos. Tama shuts down the power inside the building so that they cannot go any further than the sixth floor, and he alerts all other residents and criminals inside that will be rewarded becoming permanent residents if they kill the intruders. Sergeant Jaka learns that the mission was not authorised by the department, so there is no one that knows they are raiding the building or that will be coming to help them, and eventually after lengthy battle and lots of gunfire only six members of the team remain. Sergeant Jaka, Lieutenant Wahyu, Bowo (Tegar Satrya), Dagu (It Eka 'Piranha' Rahmadia) and Rama have survived the ambush, but are low on ammunition and being hunted by the various criminals, there is a point when Rama and Bowo manage to get some help from the man with his sick wife hiding in a secret passage behind a wall, they are lucky to survive gang heavies searching for them. Rama gets kidnapped by Tama's right hand man Andi (Donny Alamsyah), while the group with Jaka are caught by Tama's ruthless henchman Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian), Wahyu manages to escape, and Dagu is ordered to follow him. Mad Dog and Jaka go against each other, but they decide to drop their weapons and fight with their martial arts skills, Jaka is defeated and killed, while in Andi's apartment he reveals that Tama is his alienated brother, and he returns to Tama with Mad Dog dragging the body of Jaka, but the lead criminal saw Andi's betrayal with Rama on CCTV and stabs him in the hand. Tama is located on the fifteenth floor in a narcotics lab setting, and Rama, Wahyu and Dagu regroup to go and stop Mad Dog from beating up Andi, Rama and Andi kill Mad Dog, while Wahyu and Dagu go to get Tama. Eventually after the fighting and going up the stairs the police team members catch up to Tama, after Dagu was shot dead by Wahyu, but he goes against his original instinct and kills Tama with a shot in the head, but he cannot kill himself as well when he runs out of ammo, and in the end Rama, Bowo walk out of the apartment building with Andi and the captured Wahyu, but Andi returns to the building as the officers walk away. Also starring Verdi Solaiman as Budi, Ananda George as Ari and Iang Darmawan as Gofar. Most of the cast members make their characters memorable enough, especially the criminal mastermind protected by all his thugs inside the building, I will admit I did get a little confused with the plot towards the middle, but overall the story is enough to get, a raid in a building full of criminals armed to the teeth, obviously it is made the most exciting by the rapid gunfire, some small explosions, the martial arts fight sequences and the high violence content, it is indeed an exciting and inventive action crime thriller film. Very good!

The features that makes this stand out from all the other similar action movies is that it uses cutting edge graphics, you never heard of the actors, the original speakers are dubbed by Americans who shower the dialog with F bombs like a B-52 over its target, and it's all action -- nothing but.I only stuck around for a bit less than an hour. The rest of the film may be a cinematic masterpiece but I doubt it.There is a high-rise building occupied by ruthless gangsters. There is an isolated 20-man team of SWAT officers in Kevlar helmets who assault the high rise and must clean it out, floor by floor. There is treachery, incompetence, torture, and blood. The entire world is turned into a Boschian hellscape.Here's the structure of the film. The gangsters have outfitted the building like a fortress, with surveillance cameras, microphones, speakers, spies, and barricades. The cops assault, their attack is blunted on floor one. They talk. Then they assault again until their attack is blunted on floor two. They talk. They make it to a battered room on floor three but find they are surrounded and must chop their way through the floor to get back to floor two and their comrades. Then once more unto the breach, dear friends, while gore splatters all over the place and bullets zip in extra slow motion out of a gun barrel through a door, and through the neck of one of the skirmishers.This received some very good reviews, as it should have for those who miss the action movies of the 1980s and would like them back -- only moreso.Pfui.

The plot for this film is fairly simple; an elite group of police officer must enter a tower block in Jakarta and kill the crime lord who has made it his base. The operation will be anything but simple though; just about everybody in the building is loyal to the criminals or too afraid to defy them. To make matters worse it soon becomes apparent that the lieutenant who ordered the raid didn't get authorisation so there will be no chance of back up if things go wrong and they soon go very wrong! Most of the police are soon dead and those who aren't are out of ammunition; if they are to make it out alive they will have to rely on their wits and their martial arts skills.Most action films spend time introducing characters then have prolonged stops for exposition along the way; not 'The Raid' though. After a brief introduction to protagonist Officer Rama and a very quick explanation of who the bad guys were the raid began and once it had started the action hardly ever stopped! This wasn't CGI special effects and exploding helicopters; it was physical action that will leave you wondering just how many stunt men got injured making the film! Writer/director Gareth Evans did a great job bringing the story to the screen; the action is perfectly choreographed and the actors do a fine job. The amount of bloody, bone crunching action means this isn't for the squeamish but if you want your action films to be full on action you are sure to enjoy this.These comments are based on watching the film in Indonesian with English subtitles.

The Raid won't win any awards for originality (indeed, the film is remarkably similar to that of Dredd, which came out the same year); where it does score highly is with its eye-watering, bone-crunching fight scenes which are amongst the most brutal and breath-taking ever committed to celluloid. Once the fists and feet start flying, it's non-stop, blood-drenched action all the way!The film revolves around a team of elite armed policemen who storm a run-down tower block controlled by a gang of violent criminals, but who find themselves in serious trouble when they are ambushed by gunmen and whittled down to a handful of survivors. With this simple set-up, director Gareth Huw Evans (yes, the man behind this incredible Indonesian action flick is Welsh!!!) is free to deliver a martial arts masterpiece of adrenaline-pumping awesomeness, only the occasional ridiculously far-fetched moment (as opposed to just far-fetched) and silly plot development (the introduction of the hero's brother) preventing this from being perfect.

Review title: Without a doubt the best action movie I have ever seen...
Review_body: This movie takes Hollywood action movies and slams them to the floor leaving them out for the count, and it even picks up Chinese action movies and does the same to those. This movie is nothing short of spectacular. It is pure and raw action from start to end.The story in "The Raid: Redemption" is about a group of Indonesian SWAT members infiltrating a building to take down a drug ring and the boss. But things are just a bit too easy and not every police man in the Indonesian force is working with a clean conscience.The story, despite it being quite simple, was so amazingly captivating that there wasn't a single boring moment throughout the entire movie. It was so amazingly well put together and planned that it just worked on a great level. The movie just kept on rolling at a great pace, wrecking havoc and destruction in its wake. Sure, the story was predictable, but it was really great entertainment from start to end.As for the action sequences, which is the prime motor of this movie, well then it just knocks the air right out of you. It is spectacular, and similar to Thai action movies, where there is no wires, no staged action, it is all raw, physical, hard-hitting action. And when the punches and kicks connects, you can see that it is hard and must be painful. And that really makes this (as well as Iko Uwais previous movie, "Merantau") work so well.I enjoyed "Merantau" a lot, and it put Indonesia on the Asian movie market for me, and especially Iko Uwais impressed me. Then come this movie and totally unset the balance. It is without a doubt the most intense and best action movie - both in and out of Asia - that I have ever seen. Forget about Jet Li, Jackie Chan, Chow Yun Fat, Bruce Lee or Johnny Nguyen, Iko Uwais is a fast-rising star in the martial arts movies. If you like the Thai action star Tony Jaa, then you will also like Iko Uwais.It should also be said that Yayan Ruhian (playing Mad Dog) really is showing off impressive fighting in this movie as well. It is not all done by Iko Uwais. And it was nice to see Uwais and Ruhian bumping heads and fighting one another again (as they also bumped heads in "Merantau")."The Raid: Redemption" (though personally, I think the 'Redemption' part of the English title is unnecessary) is a movie that you have to watch if you enjoy Asian action movies (or action movies in general), because it is an adrenaline-filled, action-packed movie unlike anything else. And not only that, then it is also the most graphically and visually brutal action movies that I have seen. There are so many fight scenes where you just go "oooh" or "ouch" as Iko Uwais plows through bad guys with a knife. And the gunfight scenes are really impressive as well.It took me a while to get around to actually sit down and watch this movie, which was a huge mistake on my part, because this movie is explosive. Watch it! Trust me, you will not be disappointed! I love Asian cinema and have seen countless of Chinese, Hong Kong, Thai, Korean and Japanese action movies, but "The Raid: Redemption" totally wiped the slate clean and went straight to the top. This movie is impressive in every way; Indonesian martial arts movies throw a mean punch!

Exhilarating action film, with martial arts fight sequences that take your breath away (I was exhausted just watching them!), featuring a police raid into a massive apartment complex ran by a paranoid drug lord with an army of dope fiends, gunmen, and fighters ready to attack. Iko Uwais is the featured star, as Rama, a rookie cop with a pregnant wife and a brother (Donny Alamsyah) who is actually working for the drug-lord (Ray Sahetapy). The drug-lord has been expecting a raid sooner or later due to his connections with members of the corrupt police department (he has evidence of these connections, damning to those in the dept who need this information kept secret). Pierre Gruno is a cop responsible for the raid, secretly plotting to secure the drug-lord for his own devious purposes (briefly; it doesn't take long before his sergeant (Joe Taslim) realizes how dirty he is), with eyes on moving up the ladder in his police department, sitting at the same corrupt table as his superiors. Equipped with an army of dirtbags, Sahetapy remains bunkered in his security room at the top of the tower-like run-down apartment complex, using the intercom to talk to his men and the police who aren't killed towards the beginning (when picked off unexpectedly). Included in the mix is Yayan Ruhian, a rather small fellow but a ruthless, extremely fast, and tireless assassin with fighting skills that have no equal (at least not in a fair fight). Yayan's fight with Joe is really amazing to watch and isn't quite a long as it feelsthis is an example of just how vicious and unrelenting a fighter Yayan is. Yayan being able to withstand (for the majority) of a lopsided fight with not only the hero of the film, Iko, but Donny also just further proves how freakish he is. He seems to have countless energy and stamina, a force of nature, this Yayan. Seeing Iko combat fighter after fighter, down countless halls, through rooms, out windows, doors exploding, tables breaking or working as weapons, bodies just twisting and turning, flipping and flying, hands and legs moving so quickly you can barely see them, The Raid: Redemption gets the pulse a raising and adrenaline rising. The apartment complex is like this dilapidated fortress where men seem to be hiding in every room, up the stairs, down the stairs, ready to surface at any moment, with Iko always having to stay alert or else. The brothers reuniting is a nice little subplot, especially considering how one is a cop and the other a criminal. There's a really nifty suspense sequence where Iko and his partner Tegar Satrya are hidden behind the wall of a tenant's apartment as a group of the drug-lord's killers look for them (the use of a machete stuck in the wall, across Iko's face, is milked for all its worth). The ways some of the fight scenes seem to go as one uninterrupted take are phenomenal. The fighters and stunt personnel responsible for these action sequences (when people are thrown into objects, against walls, and to the floor, they look unforgiving, impactful, believable, and painful), along with the choreography and staging of them deserve a round of applause and countless accolades. The setting is a character unto itself, a very dangerous locale for any man of the badge to enter uninvited. What's really cool is that Iko is actually a decent actor, so he isn't just a hire in the film for his magnificent fighting skills but has acting chops as well! When you see a villain lifted off his feet, swung across the room, his body smashing into a wall, with rotted paint chips and dust shaken away, with the final thud to the floor, it is to be celebrated for just how willing some are to sacrifice themselves for our entertainment. What a movie!

This movie looked set to be a good one. Solid setup and background and the plot development seemed to be going well: devious, efficient criminals, cops in a predicament. Looked like we had a decent, gritty, realistic cop-drama on our hands. Then it all fell apart.First the plot started developing holes. Things started to seem contrived and implausible, and I kept thinking "But surely they should do (that)" and "How is that possible?".Worst of all, it suddenly became a martial arts movie. You know, the silly, over-the-top, very unrealistic, impossible-moves, impeccably-choreographed stuff. It started with one cop vs about 10 bad guys (and the cop winning of course), and then seemed to happen every chance the director got. It got to be so excessive, I was laughing (hey, maybe it was meant to be a comedy...). Turns out that every tenant in an apartment block is a martial arts master...Not only were the fight scenes gratuitously plentiful, silly and contrived, each scene went on and on and on - they seemed interminable. I started fast forwarding through them after a while.By now the plot had left town, as the fight scenes were there to carry the movie, leaving the movie an empty shell.A movie with much promise, most of which is wasted. Disappointing.

Review title: Simple action movie, as simple action movies should be like.
Review_body: We really need great big fat action-flicks like this one, at least once every couple of years, to remind us that the genre is still very much alive and still has plenty of originality and potential to it as well, as this small budget, Indonesian movie clearly demonstrates.It's really being a very simplistic movie, with both its settings and story but none of this really matters, since basically everything else is done so well.It's a very straightforward action-flick that features plenty of graphic violence in it as well. It's not only an action movie with lots of gunfights and explosions in it, it's also being a true old school material arts flick. And a really good one as well! All of the fights are very well choreographed and filmed and even features some moves that I had never seen before. It's also pretty extreme all, so expect lots of blood flying around and limbs getting crushed. This movie just doesn't ever hold back with any of its violence and it's basically being like a non-stop action spectacle.Perhaps the most surprising thing about this movie remains that it's an Indonesian production. A country that isn't exactly known for its cinema but this movie absolutely looks and feels like a big, multi-million dollar production, with lots of talent and experienced involved, both in front and behind the cameras. Nothing about this movie indicates that it got made with a fairly small budget and with not that many experienced people involved, while in fact this all was actually being the case. A true accomplishment from that perspective but also otherwise, this would had been a great movie to watch, with any sort of budget and language involved.And by saying that his movie does not have a whole lot of story in it, is perhaps not enough credit for this movie. They obviously at least attempted to give the movie some story, even while the entire movie is taking place in the same building. They even managed to give the movie some depth, also with its characters. It's true that its main storyline is a very simple and straightforward one but there is still plenty happening around it with its story and characters. It's really such a professional looking movie, with some great cinematography, editing and just overall style to it. It's brutal and graphic but not in an exploratory kind of way. In a way this movie is being more like a video game than a conventional action-flick perhaps.A great straightforward action-flick, that is a must-see for every lover of the genre, all over the world.8/10 http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

Review title: very good of its sort, but of little interest if you don't like martial arts
Review_body: A SWAT team of 20 police officers enter a seedy apartment building with the aim of advancing to the top floor to take out a crime lord. Things do not go as planned...This subtitled Indonesian movie does have some bits of plot scattered among the combat sequences but, let's be honest, anyone going to this film is almost certainly going to be going because it is an action movie loaded up with martial arts combat sequences, mostly featuring Iko Uwais. Let me state that if you don't like this sort of movie, then you are going to hate this one. If you do, then you are likely to enjoy it, because the fights are as good as any I've seen. And where Bruce Lee's fights were all about grace and Jackie Chan's were all about humour, the fights in this one are all about trying to kill the other guy.This movie is violent and brutal. I don't recall ever having seen another film which had 14 doctors in the closing credits, but I can quite understand why they were necessary.Very well directed, by the way, by a Welshman.

In the Jakarta slums, a derelict apartment building has become a no-go area - even the police are unwilling to enter.It has become a safe-house for dangerous killers and gangsters.A SWAT team infiltrate the building, under the cover of darkness, to remove its owner - a drug lord named Tama....First let's get the criticism out of the way, the plot is paper thin. That's it, nothing else.All the story is, is that there is a bunch of cops, and every level they go up in the block, gets a little bit more difficult and they become fewer, with a little bit of corruption thrown in for good measure.The film starts off very tensely, and as soon as Tama calls Lock Down, the film never lets up until the final frame.If you take Die Hard, and add a little Game of Death, you have The Raid.The fighting in this, is beyond awesome, it's awe inspiring, and if you think you will get bored of fight after fight, the little dramatic scenes, pack just as much of a punch, that you really care for these people.The writer/Director of this film clearly knows his action movies, as he has referenced nearly all the prolific action movie makers in one sense or another.I thought before seeing this, it was way over-hyped, and i was wrong, it deserves it's reputation. Like a musical, the fighting is wonderful to look at as well as hear.Easily the best action movie in the last fifteen years.

This Indonesian USA flick is a must see only for the fights going on. The story itself is very simple but nevertheless even clocking in over 90 minutes you are never bored due the action taking place.When a SWAT team arrives at an apartment to remove the drug dealer. But so far nobody from the police ever tried to do a raid on the block until now. It all goes well until they enter the building. From there on the SWAT team is under fire. Things go really wrong and the only way to survive is to break out of the building but there's more going on.This is a constant ride of adrenaline. You move from one shoot out to another fight to a man on man fight to suspense until this flick is over. I watched it with open mouth. I have never seen such fight scene's before. And on part of the violence, its' full of violence on the edge of gore. And for a hater of CGI i never had any trouble with it. Due the lack of a real story until the end this is a full action packed movie and a joy for the eye, excellent.Gore 1,5/5 Nudity 0/5 Effects 3/5 Story 1,5/5 Comedy 0/5

Written, directed and edited by Welshman Gareth Huw Evans, who together with leading man Iko Uwais and most of the core group who had worked together in their first feature film collaboration Merantau, The Raid picked up from the good groundwork established from that film, and translated big time into this, with bigger stunts and bigger action choreography. The action, oh the action, for the first time in an extremely long while, left me holding my breath, literally, before gasping for air when the dust settled. Never before had an action movie grab me by the scruff of my neck in attention like The Raid has, with eyes kept wide open for the fear of having to blink means losing out a single frame of a finishing blow. Merantau, if compared to this, was a tease of what the entire team can do, and under the martial arts choreography by Iko and Yayan Ruhian, who plays Mad Dog in the movie, the battle - tooth and nail, fight for survival type - sequences are a sight to behold.Evans handled The Raid with a deftness, building up suspense, anticipation and excitement like an old hand, despite this being only his third narrative feature film production. The level of complexity got increased here even if the scale of the film got reduced into from the sprawling city in Merantau, into a claustrophobic apartment block. There's CG enhanced firing of rifle rounds, before gun battles between opponents cook up a flurry of emptying magazines after magazines of automatic weapon rounds. When ranged weapons are no longer an option, in comes close quartered combat weapons like knives and batons against machetes and pipes, before the lowest common denominator of relying on bare knuckles, kicks, throws and the occasional head butt.To describe the action in the film would be a disservice in revealing too much, when it is best that you experience it for yourself. It's bloody, it's violent and it's no holds barred, bringing out panic, tension, and a great adrenaline rush as if putting you into the thick of the action like an embedded war journalist having to weave through attacks from all directions. In each carefully choreographed action milestone in the film, you're bound to discover many amazingly delivered fight sequence that you'll probably never seen before, keeping things really fresh even for the jaded action / martial arts film junkie, where you're bound to find a certain moment within each sequence that will serve as a talking point when the end credits roll, and providing you with rationale to just about watch the movie immediately again.Iko Uwais and Yayan Ruhian just about found the perfect holistic ingredients that go about making hard hitting action films, with a competent stunt team and martial arts crew to deliver action just as the two of them conjured, making everything feel real when the going gets rough, with an eye for detail and attention, keeping fights credible with an element of real danger put into them. You'll be catching yourself more than once wondering, how the heck did these guys do that? But they did, and it's all up on film for everyone to witness. It's testament of their talent and their brand of martial arts being worked for cinema, and with this they had shown that they've come a long way from Merantau some 3 years back, despite being their second action film with Gareth Evans.Action films from South East Asia are raking up a storm, with Thailand leading the charge, Malaysia following suit recently, but Indonesia really cranking and setting the bar really high for everyone else to follow. The cinematography here is silky smooth, with none of the bullshit that Hollywood tries to force as a standard - what with its shaky cam and up too close camera angles - THIS is something that Hollywood should wake up to, where the camera flows and moves around the action, keeping things steady to capture the absolute beauty of martial arts being executed by professional practitioners, and allowing the audience to see who's hitting what/who, with edits and cutaways being kept to a minimum and logically done, rather than to cover up the lack of real skills by the stunt team, or try to pass off the non-trained actor as a modern day superman.Chances are I will want to watch it again in Singapore when it premieres next month, with slight differences of course. The soundtrack for the local release will follow the US', meaning we'll get to listen to Mike Shinoda of Linkin Park and Joseph Trapanese's version compared to the Indonesian one, which in itself is already rocking and suited the look, feel and mood that The Raid will bring to action cinema. For those, like me, who can't wait, you can either do the same crossing overseas, or pick up the Merantau DVD available if you have not seen that film yet. It will introduce you to a different aspect of Silat, one primed for action cinema, and provide you a sneak peek into what to expect from The Raid from just about almost the same main cast and crew who had progressed leaps and bounds from there.The best action movie of the decade some say, and I'll verify and concur to that with a resounding Yes. Definitely highly recommended, where action junkies will find a new film to pay homage to, as it powers its way to my shortlist of one of the best this year has to offer.

Review title: Just a full-on crowd pleaser of the highest order
Review_body: "1 Ruthless Crime Lord, 20 Elite Cops, 30 Floors of Hell"That is the tagline for "The Raid: Redemption", a film that's sold on a straightforward premise (a SWAT team invades the tenement lair of a crime boss, many fights ensue), but never fails to deliver on its promise: an action thrill ride of relentless martial arts insanity and ungodly shootouts. And these are fight scenes that must be seen to be believed. Incredible camera work places you directly in the fight, giving the viewer the authentic feel of being in the room while two (sometimes three) men engage in a visceral exchange of body blows from lightning-fast limbs. Each fight scene strains (often snaps) credibility, as no human being would be able to stand after one of these punishing sessions. Yet there's the main character (you'll know the hero when you see him), moving from one off-the-wall fight to the next, maiming bad guys in groups.But that's what makes "The Raid" so incredibly watchable. It doesn't take long to go from raid movie to superhero film, as the numbers of the SWAT team drastically dwindle, and we're left with the main guy to do all of the ass-kicking. And he does it with a tremendous sense of heroism; we desperately want this guy to succeed and make it out of that building. So the unrelenting violence and brutality are easier to digest when the audience is overwhelmed with the fist-pumping satisfaction of seeing the superhero clean out the scumbags standing in his way. Unrealistic? Yes, times a thousand. But son of a bitch if it didn't make for one hell of a ride.8/10

Review title: if you have fond memories of early Hong Kong movies and 70s Jackie Chan, this is for you.
Review_body: Filmed in Jakarta with an Indonesian cast and crew this is an undoubted tour de force from Welsh director Gareth Evans. It begins at full pelt with an armed police team going into a notorious tower block inhabited by a motley crew of baddies, all connected, in one way or another with the drug trade and affiliated criminal activities. As soon as the ferocious action begins I am that, yes, I realised this was what the film was about (a clue is in the title) but can this hold my attention for forty minutes? Actually, although the trick here is not to cut to other activity or pause for a romantic interlude but instead to vary the instruments of war. So, from the automatic weapons of the opening we go all the way to extreme hand to hand and foot to foot martial arts and there is little time to stop to think. We even switch heroes to ring the changes and develop the story a little. But it is the fights, varied, fast and wonderfully choreographed that truly dominate this unique film, Not sure that I am ready for the two and a half hour follow up but this is very impressive and if you have fond memories of early Hong Kong movies and 70s Jackie Chan, this is for you.

'The Raid: Redemption' is an action-packed film, about the good fighting the evil. Well-Made & agreeably claustrophobic, this one's A Rousing BloodBath.'The Raid: Redemption' Synopsis: A S.W.A.T. team becomes trapped in a tenement run by a ruthless mobster and his army of killers and thugs.Before I write any further, let me know inform the Faint-Hearted to stay miles away from 'The Raid: Redemption'. The brutality from start to end, will put you off completely. I myself looked from the screen, due to its relentless violence. But, for action-junkies, 'The Raid: Redemption' is their orgasm. I mean, wow! The Action-Sequences are brilliantly performed & executed. Each & Every Stunt packs a punch. The Action, here, is simply mind blowing!On the whole, despite a few narrative hiccups, 'The Raid: Redemption' pushes the action genre ahead with a fierce kick.

Review title: Brutal and relentless, but where's the suspense?
Review_body: The Raid: Redemption is being called the best action film in years and one of the finest martial arts flicks in many a moon. I can certainly see why. The film is relentless and brutal in its depiction of wild, merciless carnage, with one goon after another being punched, kicked, stabbed, shot, or killed. Back in the thirties, things like this were considered outlandish. There is now an entire genre devoted to the same acts that were frowned upon many decades ago.I'm not a huge fan of modern action films. I consider many of them lousy, indistinct, generic, underdeveloped and sometimes, degrading and blatantly insulting to a generation. The Raid won me over for the first forty minutes with its scummy atmosphere and stylized sequences, but I grew weary of it all, and by the end, I felt my journey through this world of brutality could've ended twenty-five minutes earlier.The film occupies a skeleton of a plot, revolving around Rama (Uwais), a rookie member of an elite SWAT team. Deep in the Jakarta (the film is shot in Indonesia) slums, there is a decrepit, disgusting tenant occupied by the ruthless drug-lord Tama Riyandi (Sahetapy) on the thirtieth floor. The remainder of the tenant houses Rivandi's gang members, killers, druggies, and murderers. The place is so scummy and unjust that the police dare not even bother with it.The SWAT team of twenty men arrive at the break of dawn to raid the building and apprehend and kill everyone inside. The course of the film follows the SWAT team as they go floor by floor shooting, punching, and kicking their enemies until a bodies crowd the floors. This is a violent and dehumanizing exercise, but according to them, it must be done. The film as a whole is rigid and remorseless, and sadly, no character, even out main protagonist, is never developed at all. They are action figures in SWAT uniforms. That's how far the film goes.The film has the plot of a Nintendo Entertainment System game, and the look and feel of a Call of Duty extravaganza on Xbox 360. As far as the action goes, it's very coherent and stylistic. Coherency is my biggest complaint when it comes to modern action films. Many action films, take Taken and Transformers for example, have potential to be well done and very intriguing pictures, but what winds up happening is character development is swapped for fighting and coherency traded for jumbled, fast-moving sequences. The Raid: Redemption's stunts are hard to document, but never once was I lost in the shuffle. Everything was there and it was all projected in a coherent and consistent state. Something I must laud.But here's the prime complaint; the film violates one of my rules of action films. This is one of the things I knocked Taken for as well. If you have a man who can beat up x-number of guys on screen at one time, where is the suspense? If a person can apparently survive all attempted punches and kicks, and somehow dodge ones forthcoming and know every move their enemy is going to make, where does the fear that "he'll slip or get captured" come in? The Raid: Redemption has all the pieces together, but it lacks credible suspense and tension in its sequences.The martial arts genre hasn't been explored by me enough, and The Raid is an interesting first step. If I went by reviews online, I'd think I had witnessed a game-changer or even a masterpiece. Now here's where my job breeds contempt; do I recommend the film? This is one of those films where if you read the plot, you don't need anyone to tell if you will like it or not. You should know by hearing the words "SWAT team," "fighting," "brutality," "relentless," and "violence." People will pay to see the film, and it is already receiving enthusiastic praise online. But my job is not to review the film from an audience perspective. My job is to give my opinion and say if I recommend it. To action fans, it will do its job and to them, it will be a strong, worthy picture. For me, it was thin and lacking in substance.Starring: Iko Uwais, Joe Taslim, and Donny Alamsyah. Directed by: Gareth Evans.

Review title: Double bill - The Raid and The Raid 2
Review_body: Double bill time, Welsh filmmaker Gareth Evans has made a big splash with his action one-two punch which puts the Indonesian martial art "Pencak Silat" on a bigger map. Swimming against the tide of an inexorably digitized world, since the noughties, action movies have been experiencing a somewhat fundamentalistic revolution ushered in by ONG-BAK: THE THAI WARRIOR (2003), where a more tactile, point-blank and lethal combat style greatly relying on the performers' physical prowess sounding the death knell for a plethora of CGI-heavy schlock, and Gareth Evans takes the revolution further down that road, at any time of the day, it is more than welcomingBlanketed in its slate blue hue, THE RAID: REDEMPTION has a setting like a single-location entrapment horror flick, a catastrophic heavy blow incurs to a team of elite squad when they raid inside a tenement tower block owned by the crime lord Tama Riyado (Sahetapy) in Jakarta's slums, it turns out to be a set-up as a corollary of corruption among police top-brass. Assailed by not zombies but practically zombie-looking inhabitants (bedraggled drug addicts mostly) and a cohort of Tama's henchmen, they might find some painful irony (if they are still breathing) from recollecting the paradoxical pep talk of Sergeant Jaka (Taslim), who is leading the raid, paraphrasing here: it is a highly dangerous mission, but I don't want to see any of those seats empty when we return. The one who is bestowed with a protagonist nimbus is Rama (Uwais), a tyro in the forces and has an ax to grind in the game, when all the ammo is expended, his killer martial art skill starts to tip the scale in the bloodshed. Since its no-account story-line seldom fluctuates with plot development (barring a fraternal reunion), and although many tropes of suspense routinely deployed to the hilt, it is the action pieces taking our breath away, the go-for-the-jugular (joints, limbs, and other more cardinal parts) pragmatism and Evans' lenience on blood and guts, skewered together one set piece after another, our rapt attention becomes a given, and the brutal aesthetics reaches its crescendo in the close-range combat between Rama, his brother Andi (Alamsyah) and Tama's top muscle, a disheveled Mad Dog (Ruhian, who is a martial art virtuoso and the fight choreographer for both movies, also plays a completely different character in the sequel). After REDEMPTION successfully testing the water, THE RAID 2: BERANDAL (which means thug in Indonesian) is expectedly souped up by a significantly boosted budget and an ampler length (150 minutes, 50 minutes longer than the first installment). Mapping out an ambitious gangster turf war saga, Evans' script swiftly sends Rama to the joint to befriend Uco (Putra), the son of Bangun (Pakusadewo), one of the two kingpins of Jakarta's underworld, where a muddy mêlèe during a downpour set alight the first frisson of excitement (it is a virtue Evans doesn't overuse the worn- out slo-mo shtick, after THE MATRIX 1999 and its countless emulators, enough is enough). In fact, the resultant story veers more towards Uco's ill-conceived subversion, and Putra, not quite a martial artist himself but commendably takes up the gauntlet as a pompous gilded youth, too thrusting and wanting both wits and patience to mellow into a rightful heir of his father's cosmic empire, particularly when there is nothing to imperil his standing, what is the fuss anyway? Maybe like in every patriarch's incubus, he is just a bad seed and driven at lengths to carry out a patricidal sin, Putra's performance is vehement, visceral and transforms Uco as the film's heart of matter, a grab bag of what is wrong with today's youngsters. In the action section, on the one hand, Evans continues choreographing striking fighting sequences of Pencak Silat, and playing up the possibility of orchestration within a two-by-four space (a prison bathroom, or inside a barreling car); on the other hand, in tandem with an enclosed fistfight, he also cuts his teeth into a sterling car chase set piece with an ace in his sleeve, and what an adrenaline rush it spurs! Although it would be remiss of me to not mention a congenital hiccup rather common in action fares, those conspicuous ready-to-take-the-hit poses or caesuras, mostly from foot soldiers during their meager screen-time, it immediately dispels the "realness" of all the onerously rehearsed teamwork. The most pyrotechnic eye-catcher is indubitably the final showdown between Rama and the karambit-knives-wielding killer, credited as the Assassin (Rahman), which makes Very Tri Yulisman's Baseball Bat Man and Julie Estelle's Hammer Girl quite bathetic in their gore-fest, not to mention the boss who prefers heavy weaponry but is inept enough to toss it to the wrong one when the crunch comes.Both movies are cracking genre pieces made with labor of love, devotion and dexterity, and Evans' directorial flair takes a crucial peg up under the sequel's grander scale, blissfully, one can see the potential in a filmmaker which can unbridle the genre parameters.

Review title: One of the best action movies of 2011
Review_body: This has got to be one of the best action movies of 2011. Tony Jaa was the new face for martial arts flick when Ong-Bak came out which introduced Muay Thai into action flicks. This time it's Iko Uwais with a Indonesian martial arts pencak silat which is indeed a entertaining martial arts style to watch. It has other martial arts style in the movie but the main focus is silat. This movie is so cool that I am sure the makers for the movie "Dredd" got a lot of ideas from this flick. This movie is almost a non-stop martial arts action with some shootouts. And the execution of it all is just superb. Like what it says on the DVD cover it's 30 floors of fighting chaos. I just about enjoyed every minute of this movie and looking forward to more works from Gareth Evans who directed this movie. And is a avid fan of martial arts movies. Gareth Evans is one of those directors that claim they only make movies they want to see on screen. And don't put much thought on what other mainstream audiences are into. I for one enjoyed just about every aspect of this movie. Although this flick doesn't have a big budget going for it, they really did a great job with what they had. A sequel is also in the planning and just can't wait for it.8.4/10

Review title: Plays out like a violent video game with attackers continuously piling out of apartment rooms as characters move through various floors (levels)!
Review_body: 'THE RAID: REDEMPTION': Four Stars (Out of Five) Indonesian action/horror film teaming director and writer Gareth Evans with star Iko Uwais (the two also teamed on the 2009 Martial Arts action film 'MERANTAU'). Like their first collaboration this film is filled with fight scenes featuring the Indonesian Martial Art pencak silat, choreographed by stars Uwais and Yayan Ruhian (who plays the villain of the film). It tells the story of a rookie SWAT team tasked with bringing down a viscous mobster residing in a fortress like apartment building, protected by drug dealers and killers. The movie is extremely violent and dark but it's also one hell of a thrill ride. Action and Martial Arts fans are sure to be delighted.The majority of the film is set in an apartment building in Jakarta's slums. It houses some of the most vicious and ruthless criminals and killers in the area and their lead by mobster Tama Riyadi (Ray Sahetapy). A rooki SWAT team is assigned to enter the building (that even the cops are afraid to step foot in) and bring Tama to justice. What they don't know is that the mission has been put together solely by the corrupt Lieutenant Wahyu (Pierre Gruno), with his own agenda, and no reinforcements will be sent in to assist them if needed. Tama knows this and surrounds the building with his thugs trapping the police inside to be killed one by one. A battle ensues as the film focuses on one strong willed Muslim cop named Rama (Uwais) as he struggles to survive the onslaught of death and carnage.Like I said the film is graphically violent and gruesome and the tone of the film very much leans towards the horror genre. It also plays out very much like a violent video game with attackers continuously piling out of apartment rooms as characters move through various floors (levels). It's a little too dark for my taste but it is a fun ride nonetheless. The fight scenes are brilliantly choreographed and the action is spectacular. Of course none of it is the tad bit realistic but movies like this aren't supposed to be. It's a visceral ride, a very violent one at that. The director and stars are sure to move on to bigger and better things and the film is already set for an American remake and two sequels!Watch our movie review show 'MOVIE TALK' at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xh674mS5vTo
Great action movie. suspenseful throughout, lots of great scenes. the hand to hand combat was superb and very creative. fast and hard-hitting. this is a straight action movie (3 viewings)

Review title: Thrill a minute action spectacular of a kind Hollywood won't make anymore
Review_body: STAR RATING: ***** Saturday Night **** Friday Night *** Friday Morning ** Sunday Night * Monday MorningIn Jakarta, Indonesia, a SWAT team mount a drugs raid on a tower block where a ruthless dealer and his henchmen operate. Expecting a routine bust, they under-estimate how ruthless the criminal is prepared to be and how much of an effective army he has at hand, and find themselves trapped in a massive concrete jungle, where martial arts killers lurk at every corner and only one side will take more casualties. One cop (Ido Kuwais) must race against time to save the day.With the advent of CGI and wire fu, the novelty of genuine martial artists, such as Steven Seagal and Jean Claude Van Damme, performing their on screen daring do in Hollywood has lost it's edge, with us now living in a day and age where anyone can be a martial artist. So thank Heavens we can still turn to Asian cinema, which still makes a big deal out of showcasing the real deal. While stars from the past, such as Jackie Chan and Jet Li, seem to have left more of a legacy behind them than more recent discoveries such as Ong-bak's Tony Jaa, there is a new hope in the shape of Ido Kuwais, the lead star of this new raved about action piece, and his exponing of the fighting art of Silat, which this film shows in it's fastest, most breath taking and thrilling style.Director Gareth Evans, whose previous two features appear to be even more unknown and off the beaten track than this one, generates a genuine air of suspense and claustrophobia as events unfold, with the viewer really feeling locked in with the cops as they learn just how fu*ked they are and how everyone isn't telling the truth. The fight choreography is extremely impressive, displaying a real skill for the art while not forgetting to make it as fast, brutal and thrilling as it can be. Kuwais doesn't especially stand out as an action hero, but portraying a fairly generic Asian action star performs his duties with aplomb. In general, the script, acting and dialogue aren't first rate, but the film delivers where it was supposed to, and that's what matters.God knows the lazy cookie cutting machine that is Hollywood is re0making enough things at the moment- I'm sure their placid interpretation of this will soon be in our eyes. ****

When it comes to sheer, unrelenting action, 'The Raid (2011)' is hard to beat. Though the premise is simple, the plot doesn't just feel like an excuse for all its chaos. That's primarily because the storytelling is efficient, not basic. It portrays its narrative as something that's part of a wider world while still making it feel holistic, a fast-paced rollercoaster ride with a few twists and turns for good measure. The major characters aren't just cardboard cut-outs, either. They're archetypes, yes, but they have a decent amount of depth to them and are presented in a remarkably compelling light. The protagonist, Rama, is made instantly empathetic by a brief but important sequence showcasing his home-life and pregnant wife. While this isn't exactly unique, it's absolutely vital and it - along with a few other moments along the way - establishes our lead as someone you genuinely want to survive the eponymous raid-gone-wrong. After a suspenseful build-up, the piece explodes in a hail of bullets, bolo knives and brutal beatings. Make no mistake: this is a survival film. Its insurmountable odds truly feel insurmountable, as an endless parade of thugs mercilessly hunt down our trapped heroes. The picture achieves a brilliant balance between edge-of-your-seat tension and pulse-pounding action. Though it's the latter that typically gets the most attention, the former is equally as important in making the thing as gripping and exciting as it is. Having said that, the action is spectacular. Thanks to handheld camerawork, crunchy sound design and impactful gore, the fight sequences hit as hard as possible. They're fast, frenetic and brutal, choreographed to perfection. They're some of the best in the genre and are a treat to experience, always complimenting the wider narrative while telling their smaller tales. When it comes down to it, the action doesn't work as well on its own as it does in the context of the wider film, which proves that the flick is much more than just a compilation of set-pieces. It's atmospheric and enthralling throughout. 8/10

Who'd have thought that Indonisia would raise the bar when it came to action movies? 'The Raid' is hardly the most complicated film to review, but, if you're into your gunplay and marshal-arts then you can't go far wrong here. Oh, and you'll need to be okay with subtitles.Basically, the film is about a police raid on a towerblock containing some of the toughest (and deadly) criminals around. And – guess what – things don't go too well for our boys in blue. It isn't long before their bodies start piling up, leaving only our plucky new recruit (who just so happens to be damn good at kicking people) to survive and untangle the mess that's quickly building up.If you're wondering what makes this so much better than all the other action movies out there – it's the 'look' (well, for starters anyway). It has a very professional and gritty feel to it. The director (who, to my shame, I've never heard of) has obviously spent a lot of time framing each shot to give it quite a nice – almost 'arty' – feel. Then there are the fight scenes – they're meticulously choreographed and, despite being technically as unrealistic as the next marshal arts film, they are really good fun to watch.The actors are basically cast according to their looks. Bad people are ugly and good people have nice hair. However, at least everyone plays their part well and, even though all the talking is subtitled, it seems that everyone can actually act as well as is required for beating people to a pulp.There are a few twists and turns in the plot – some you may see coming, others are less obvious. But I won't go into them too much. All you need to know is that, if you're okay with subtitles and love marshal arts or action films, then you'll enjoy The Raid (and its sequel, if you're curious about that!).

Review title: The fight scenes are something else!
Review_body: There was so much hype surrounding this movie, I was a bit let down the first time I viewed it. Recently, with the hype out-of-the-way, I decided to give it another shot with a clear head. I'm glad I did! This is an insane action movies that has almost everything an action fan could want. What I liked about it is the pacing. The first half is paced perfectly. It builds up the story very well, giving you a chance to get to know the main characters. Character development was pretty decent in this one, which I appreciated. Let's not fool ourselves, though! The main selling point is the action, and chances are, that's what you've come to see. The effects are relatively cheap, but a big budget wasn't needed. The tenement makes a wonderful setting, and even adds to the atmosphere. It feels rightly tattered. You won't be disappointed by the fight scenes! There are many fights that stand out, but the 2 on 1 fight between Iko Uwais & Joe Tasim against a ridiculously skilled (Ruhian) is the highlight. Those that like slow motion shootouts ( I don't) should enjoy as well. I predicted the twists, but that doesn't mean I didn't enjoy the ride. Iko Uwais is definitely one of the most exciting new action stars. He reminds me of Tony Jaa, albeit less flashy. He's so fast, the camera couldn't keep up with him at times. This guy is certainly someone people should keep an eye on! Joe Tasim had instant chemistry with Uwais, and their conflict was not only endearing, but believable. Yayan Ruhian is a monster that you have to see to believe. He scared the crap out of me! Hopefully Hollywood notices the talent this guy has. The violence is pretty extreme, though not as violent as the sequel, which I have yet to see. This is an awesome action movie! Nothing more, nothing less. Adrenaline junkies have no business putting this movie off any longer! I can't wait to see the sequel8.3/10

The Raid: RedemptionFinally! Hollywood has made a movie about the forgotten frivolity of a good, old-fashioned panty raid.What's that? This action movie was made in Indonesian, and there are no female dormitories in it?A dilapidated apartment becomes the prime directive of the Jakarta SWAT team after the high-rise is hijacked by a kingpin, Tama (Ray Sahetapy), and turned into a fortified safe haven for Jakarta's worst criminals.While officers Rama (Iko Uwais) and Jaka (Joe Taslim) safely enter the building, Tama soon locks all exits and puts the inhabitants on attack.Forced to fight throngs of armed assailants, the pair receives help from a familiar face out of Rama's past.While it does start off sluggish, once the surprise narrative kicks in and the martial arts intensifies, The Raid: Redemption is finally redeemed.As for staging a raid on an apartment, remember: bullet holes come out of the damage deposit. (Yellow Light)vidiotreviews.blogspot.ca

This review is for the English language version.I am still terrified by the stunts, the martial art stunts, which Wikipedia has a term for. Every other sequence culminates into an action scene & the crescendo is different for each. That makes the movie very unpredictable. These are the two reasons which makes me rate it 7.0/10.Acting isn't that great with shaky cinematography. Music is absolute & extremely parallel to the pensive screenplay. Implications are high & that is one negative for this action classic. It successfully hooks you into the plot without boring you. Certain parameters (call them add-ons) which are faintly related to emotions add to the glory of movie- watching. The dubbing made me upset, but its okay!BOTTOM LINE: Very good action flick without cheap tactics.MESSAGE: If you help someone, they will help you back... sometime!Can be watched with a typical Indian family? NOProfanity: Mild | Violence: Infinity | Gore: Infinity | Smoking, Drugs: No | Alcohol: Very Mild | Sex, Nudity: No

Well, there are actually some quite helpful Youtube channels when it comes to movies in that they actually make recommendations for films that tend to slip under the radar. This is one of those films, and the fact that it came out of Indonesia is certainly one of the reasons that I wouldn't have heard of it, nor would I have thought of actually watching it. Another thing is that it appeared on the SBS streaming service in Australia, which meant that when it came around to watching an SBS film, I pretty much took this one straight away.So, there is this building in the middle of Jakarta which happens to be controlled by this gang and it is basically impenetrable. However, the cops decide they want to take it down, though there are suggestions that things aren't quite above board, especially when the boss suggests that cops can be bought where as rival gangs need to be dealt with. Well, when I say that it is impenitrable is certainly is because the cops get taken out pretty quickly, though a handful survive, and they realise that they need to get out.The entire action pretty much takes place in the building (though there are a couple of scenes outside), so you could say that this film follows the unity of time, place, and action. Well, there is an awful lot of action in the film, and I certainly wonder how they managed to make this film without half of the actors actually getting injured. In fact, I suspect that there were an awful lot of injuries in this film - it certainly is nowhere near as tame as some of the American films that you tend to get.The other thing is the martial arts. At first I thought that this film was simply going to be a lot of machine guns going off, but the thing is that the cops that do manage to survive end up without any weapons, so they need to resort of their fists. In fact, I never expected an Indonesian film to have such hard core martial arts in it, and this movie certainly doesn't let you down in that regards, especially as you get closer to the end.Yeah, this film is pretty cool, especially if you really like your action, and have been yearning for some of that old school Hong Kong action which certainly seems to have gone by the wayside of late. I can't necessarily say that Indonesia has picked it up, but with this being the first Indonesian film that I've seen, I have to admit that I really like what has come out. It also reminds me that sometimes some of these movie recommendation channels on Youtube are worth checking out, especially if you want something slightly different to the norm.

Job well done, director Gareth Evans! This was an action-packed thrill ride with great visuals and photography. Fast-paced and brutal, the fight scenes are incredibly well choreographed. Be warned, though, this is a very, very violent film, but done with style. The stunts are amazing.Iko Uwais was fantastic as the protagonist and it is no wonder he was approached by Hollywood after this film. I loved the music, as well. This is a superb production, although it might not appeal to everyone due to the violence.

Trapped in a towering apartment complex run by a drug lord and his minions, an Indonesian SWAT team have fight their way out after their lieutenant reveals that their mission was never actually approved by his superiors in this high octane action thriller. Pierre Gruno is well cast as the world-weary lieutenant in question who gradually comes to doubt his decision to go rogue with his team. He has some excellent moments towards the end as he has to contend with the verbal torments of the drug lord. There is also a young SWAT member who we soon find out has some personal baggage with the mission. For the most part though, the film is one unrelenting action scene after another and the endlessness has an unwelcome mind-numbing effect. Magnificently choreographed as all the action sequences are, they are not quite as powerful without quiet moments in between to space them out; the carnage also loses its squirm value with so much grisliness constantly filling up the screen. It seems quite telling that the film's best scene is one without a single fight as two SWAT members hide out in a hollow wall with the drug lord's minions within inches of spotting them. It is a sequence full of suspense, whereas the majority of the film works on account of simpler thrills and chills. If taken as a pure visceral experience though, the film is admittedly very well done. The set design, full of eerily dilapidated hallways and many dark crevasses is simply spectacular, and the at times pulsating music score is pitch perfect throughout, providing an air of unease to every single scene.

Review title: The movie that all action movies will now be compared to
Review_body: Released amongst a flurry of post-Expendables 80's action homages, The Raid arrived to be met with almost universal acclaim from audiences and critics alike. So while Stallone and his crew have wetted audiences appetites for big guns and corny dialogue again - that coincidentally coincided with the return of the original oiled-up arse-groper, Arnold Schwarzenegger - The Raid took action back to the hand-to-hand delights of Asian action cinema and created what is undoubtedly the finest collection of fisticuffs that has ever been committed to film. Made with little budget, an inexperienced cast, and a director from Wales (the movie itself is Indonesian), the result is simply mystifying, blowing away all pretenders.The plot is simple. Expectant father Rama (Iko Uwais) and a 20-man police squad led by Sergeant Jaka (Joe Taslim) and Lieutenant Wahyu (Pierre Gruno) are sent to an apartment block run by crime lord Tama (Ray Sahetapy). Made up mainly by rookies, the team intend to sneak in undetected, taking Tama and his two henchmen Andi (Donny Alamsyah) and Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian) alive. Things don't go to plan when they are seen by a spotter and are quickly confronted by a small army of the apartment block's residents. With the squad separated and quickly getting smaller, and Lieutenant Wahyu's intentions becoming increasingly unclear, Tama announces that any man that kills a policeman will be allowed to live there free of charge, causing even more cronies to descend on them.While the plot sounds distinctly similar to that of Die Hard (1988) (and one copied by Dredd a year later), the set-up is a simple platform to allow director Gareth Evans to unleash a near-endless orgy of fists, feet, knives and, well, more fists. Had the action been anything less than spectacular, The Raid would be a massive bore, but thankfully, it is jaw-dropping. Every fight is a lightning-fast array punches and kicks with spatters of black humour and squirm-inducing deaths. Yet there are no bone-snapping close-ups or time-altering impact accentuations that plague action movies with lesser scope and respect for it's audience - this is fast, brutal, almost real. Sure, the characters simply defy the limits of the human pain threshold, but it's the realism of the punches and stabbings that give the fights their impact.You will need to leave your brain at the door however, as beyond the action scenes, there is very little going on in terms of story and believability, which makes the film somewhat shallow in terms of what it could have been given a little more thought. Every resident in the apartment complex is a master of some martial art or other. But that I can easily forgive, as it just offers the chance to make every single fight memorable. If you loved the famous fight scene in They Live, then you're in for a treat towards the end, where we get a truly nasty extended three-way face-off, that displays some fine martial artistry that will surely put pencak silat on the movie map. The Raid is destined to be the film that all action movies are compared with, and undoubtedly silenced by. Sadly, with the absence of any real plot developments, The Raid will always be a great action movie to me, rather than a great movie.

The Raid Redemption is a film which delves into the atmosphere of more past times Asian action films. Although the film is low on plot, and think on character development, the constant action is what the viewers are tuned into. The action sequences are shot well and at times can be intense. The film isn't too predictable, besides knowing the hero is unstoppable. The Raid provides enough action to keep hardcore buffs locked in for 100 minutes. We see how everything happens and it is a well wait. Scenes which include the lead hero taking on over 20 recruits at a time and confidently killing them all, or where the lead takes one recruit and dives out the window satisfyingly killing him. The brutal violence delivers as it starts right from the beginning until the final few scenes.There is definitely an audience for these types of films, and for those whom are not interested in these films, would more than less not enjoy it.

While I've ragged on video game violence in the past, I have to admit that I liked THE RAID: REDEMPTION. The non-stop, full-speed-ahead action makes for fun viewing- but, like casual sex with a stranger, it lacks a lasting impact. Why do I say this? Because I just recently saw it for the SECOND time and didn't realize until I was well into it that I'd ALREADY seen it. (This sometimes happens with martial arts movies, especially when they've been re-titled, but this one wasn't retitled.) Being a boxing and mixed martial arts fan (not to mention a martial arts movie fan), I can appreciate action (violence) for its own sake. (Just recently, for instance, I saw the Georges St. Pierre-Johnny Hendricks title fight and I was genuinely surprised: judging from the comments by the so-called "experts," the fight had been a one-sided affair handily won by Hendricks. Not so. St. Pierre won four out of five rounds, at the very least. Sometimes, you just have to see it for yourself...) There's enough action in THE RAID: REDEMPTION to give the viewer a concussion. It's sometimes a cross between a martial arts movie and a professional wrestling match (a LOT of contact appears to have been made along the way and, although the intention of the players obviously wasn't intentional harm to one another, they often pushed the envelope- hard). If there's a drawback to it all, it's the total lack of story (the failing of all too many action movies these days); in that respect, it IS not unlike a video game.

Review title: The Raid is the Indonesian version of Dredd.
Review_body: I know this was released first but I couldn't get it out of my head! We follow a SWAT team who raid an apartment block in order to capture Pa-Pa, but the Pa-Pa clan aren't going to make it easy...(ok fine, no more Dredd references). One minute in and our main character is punching, elbowing and kicking a sand bag at 100mph. Bam! I was ready to sit back and watch a heck load of hand combat unfold. 40 minutes later, still no hand combat scenes...I was growing agitated. Thankfully though, the film turned around and our main character was battling his way through using only his body and knives. I'm talking full annihilation. Complete decimation. The residents did not stand a chance! Wham! Bam! Kapow! Swish! Slice! Followed by continuous noises as our characters fights to death. "Ah! Ehh! Phwoarrr! Hai! Ohhh!"...you get the gist. The action is pretty relentless, well executed and rapid. The choreography is insane. INSANE! There is one scene where two good guys are against one bad guy (apologies for the bland description) that goes on for six minutes. I have never seen so much flipping, kicks to the head, jump punches and head smashes to the floor...in my life. The bad guy in that scene is like the Indonesian Terminator, he just wouldn't die. The directing was good overall, not many quick cuts although the camera was particularly shaky during the first half. My problems with the film are with the plot conveniences and predictability. I don't really want to dive into it for spoiler reasons but if our main character is in a tricky situation, something would always happen to get him out. Any "twists" that were executed, were predictable and poorly constructed. Also some fight scenes in rooms have all the furniture right next to the walls, therefore leaving a massive open space for the fight. I would like to have seen them use the furniture to their advantage. Plus, I literally just watched it and don't know the main character's name. At all. Greatest action movie ever? No, but it's good!

"The Raid: Redemption" is a great ride of a movie. There is little plot. It's all action. The action is terrifically choreographed. They may actually be too much action in this movie. It's an exhausting movie to watch. There is very little, if any, comic relief. That's why "The Raid: Redemption" feels a little long towards the end. It wears you down after a while. But until you get tired, it's great stuff.

Review title: bone shattering, jaw dropping, brutal, high octane, non-stop action fiesta
Review_body: This is the second collaboration of Evans and Uwais after their first action film, Merantau, released in 2009. Both films showcase the traditional Indonesian martial art Pencak Silat, with fight choreography by Uwais and Yayan Ruhian, who also worked on Merantau. After watching merantau, i was waiting anxiously for the raid redemption. Didn't had the hope that it might release in India. There was no endorsements or trailers on Indian channels. No marketing, but just a small ad in Bombay Times newspaper. I was rejoiced after i came 2 know that its releasing in theater. I had hope in Gareth n Uwais, but many ppl here was not aware of 'em. If you like martial arts movies, this one will blow you away! The choreography on the fight scenes is insane. This movie is a bone-shattering symphony of brutal fight sequences, awesome gun play and heart-thumping tension. The Raid's main lead played by the impressive Iko Uwais and the film's fiercest villain Yayan Ruhian are both incredibly skilled, life-long practitioners of the lesser known Indonesian martial art Pencak Silat. Awesome direction n writing by Gareth Evan. Really hats off to him for giving us (action movie junkies ) a masterpiece like this. Awesome editing by Gareth Evan. U don't feel bore even for a single minute. Best choreography by iko uwais n yayan ruhian. Nice cinematography by Matt flannery.

Review title: Old school martial arts mixed with B-movie violence in a concise and effective way
Review_body: The martial arts showcase movie, completely pure and unapologetic, has become a lost genre it seems. If nothing else, director Gareth Evans uses "The Raid: Redemption" to bring pencak silat to audiences all over the world in this manner, but he also manages to create an action movie that satisfyingly merges B-movie violence with a true physical art form.The story of "The Raid" is neatly packed and delivered in a way that puts the emphasis on the characters and the action. A SWAT team is ordered to take out a crime/drug lord (Ray Sahetapy) in his 15-plus story building filled with dangerous and skilled men who are fiercely loyal to him. When they become trapped on the seventh floor, it becomes a fight for survival. One rookie cop in particular (Iko Uwais) must try to escape to return home to his wife and unborn child.Some twists reveal themselves along the way, but because of the contained nature of this story, they're pleasant surprises rather than forced and obvious. Boiled down, "The Raid" is a glorified arcade game premise. The finished product turns out to be bloody mayhem on screen.Evans somehow manages to strike a balance between fearful realism and over-the-top video- game violence. Larger action sequences take the shape of the latter, but the film takes numerous occasions to slow down and work the suspense so that the bigger, ultra- choreographed action feels like a culmination or climax. A scene where our hero, Rama, hides with his injured comrade in an apartment wall is of particular note on the more suspenseful side of things. The script recognizes that too much of one kind of action will kill the effectiveness of the entire product.The fight scenes are more creative toward the front of the film and sort of unravel into pure pencak silat choreography toward the end, namely because all the weapons have run out of ammo and all the knives buried into peoples' chests, necks, knees, etc. Perpetuating the video game analogy, much of the fights feel like stages/missions as well as mini-bosses, etc. If you enjoy that structure in gaming, "The Raid" will hit that same spot in a satisfying way.But what really makes "The Raid" work, or at least go beyond a lifeless and gory demonstration of Indonesian martial arts, is how the script works in subplots. Some characters are given moral ambiguity, some pure motivation ... basically, effort was taken with the writing to up the stakes of the mayhem. It might not be great writing or even that original, but it will motivate most people to root for Rama and against a myriad of thugs and other characters.It might be tough for Evans to replicate the success of the film with future outings now that pencak silat has more exposure and will consequently feel less novel, but "The Raid" offers a pleasant martial arts throwback mixed with a more contemporary violent action style that will work for anyone who identifies as an old-school action purist.~Steven CThanks for reading! Visit moviemusereviews.com for more!
