The Raid Redemption is one great action movie with awesome action and fight sequances and some of the best choreography of fighting that I ever see.So all I can say is how this film deserves cult status and its reputation is well deserved .

Review title: Never seen such a bloody ballet of violence before
Review_body: Story: cop plans a raid on a building owned by a druglord. 90 minutes of contineous fighting in this building is what follows. "The Raid" is just the ultimate frenzy of violence, performed as if it were a bloodfilled ballet. It feels like a violent ballet because the stuntmen are real life fighters and the fight scenes are choreographed very realistically. Even after 5 times watching it I am still amazed by the beauty of the fighting scenes and shocked by the cruelties committed."The Raid" is unlike any other action movie I have ever witnessed in decades. This must be watched only by adults. Really NOT suited for the faint hearted, becasue the violence is so real and gruesome. "The Raid" is 90 minutes of a rollercoaster ride filled with blood and death. But despite all the violence there is still a good story to be found amongst the piles of dead bodies. It is not just a brainless fight movie. It really has got a heart in its story. And the acting is very convincing and real life like too. I will never forget those faces full of fear and hate of these actors. Brilliantly casted and performed. After 5 times rewatching this movie over the years, some fighting scenes stretched a bit too long for my taste: how much contineous violence can one absorb without getting numb? But that's my only small criticism. Would have rated it a 10 otherwise. Now I think this is the almost perfect action movie. 9 stars. Never watched anything like this before in the action movie genre."The Raid" is undoubtedly a new classic!

Review title: Some of the best martial arts scenes of the decade
Review_body: The Raid: Redemption is a 2011 Indonesian action thriller slash martial arts film where a young special ops officer participates in a raid against a powerful mob boss holed up in a lonely highrise.A Western equivalent to this would be the 2012 Dredd film starring Karl Urban. They were filmed back to back but I wouldn't be surprised if the makers of Dredd weren't influenced by this film.Plot-wise the film is rather simplistic. A mob boss is holding down to a single location, the police special forces have to fight their way to him. Of course it's not quite that simple, but you get the gist of it.Where this film shines is in execution of its fight scenes. They squeeze every possible drop of entertainment out of this location and their stars, many of whom are accomplished practitioners of Pencak Silat, the Indonesian martial art.There are those that'll complain that this film is nothing more than one fight action scene after another. And to those people I say, this is not your film. This is a film for martial arts aficionados, who can appreciate a perfectly crafted fight scene, almost completely devout of shaky cam or jarring jump cuts. This film and its fight scenes are a thing of beauty that should be appreciated for their own merits.Pure in its simplicity yet all the more stronger for it. Definitely a must see film for fans of martial arts films.

Review title: High in quality, but lacking a soul
Review_body: I remember back in 2012 when the 'Dredd' came out, and turned out to be absolutely fantastic, everyone was comparing it to 'The Raid: Redemption' both in similarities of story line and in quality. Ever since then I've been meaning to get around to seeing it (and its sequel) and finally managed to tonight. I would say I was impressed, but not blown away. The film is absolutely non-stop action from the word go. There is zero let up from start to finish - but is that a good thing? I felt like the film never slowed down enough to allow itself to have a soul. What I mean by that is films with incredible pacing like 'The Dark Knight' (if you ever need 2 and a half hours to feel like 15 minutes, that's the film to go with) still manage to take the time to be thought-provoking. Now, 'The Raid: Redemption' is far from mindless and has some twists and turns along the way, but it never made me actually go into a deeper level of thinking on anything. This is what hinders it from being up there with the truly great films.There's a lot of of fun to had with this movie nonetheless. Some of the fight sequences are quite astonishing. I don't think the claustrophobic feel of the building was up to the same standard that 'Dredd' managed to create it to, though perhaps that was simply because this building had windows? There's certainly a lot to like here, and while it's far from perfect, I very much look forward to seeing what they managed to achieve with a bigger budget in the sequel.

One of the things I've always loved about the action genre is that like with the suspense thriller genre it's sometimes about the what ifs. Whether it being framed and forced to run, some evil organization trying to kill you, or surrounded by enemies, the joy of the action genre is on the possibility of overcoming and surviving the worst case scenario.The plot is great because it's simple and it feels plausible, whose to say no crime lord or organization ever had this ambush operation in the back of their mind. And once again it utilizes the few or one against the world scenario, I always love those types of battles because it's just always fun to think you can beat incalculable odds and survive.There real isn't much in characterization or characters, their all pretty much the typical archetypes. This film were purely in it for the action and theirs nothing wrong with that. I love the fact this film is action action it doesn't bother with any stupid boring melodrama or even complexity and twists that come out of the blue; it's simply no nonsense and straight to the point, which is what most of my favorite films are.The production value is great, it was done on a low or modest budget but it was used well and right. I really like the use of the building location, the fact it was dingy, dirty, gritty, and dark really helped give the film the element of suspense. The pacing is great almost like a video game, there is just constant action and suspense that you almost can't afford to take a breath. I really love the music score by Mike Shinoda, some parts of it were just exiting and really got your adrenaline pumping, but in the suspenseful sequences it was really suspenseful it almost felt a little reminiscent of the music I would hear in a John Carpenter film which is awesome since he's my favorite movie director.The suspense is great I really like how you do feel a sense of isolation and dread at times where the next turn in the hallway, corner, or floor could have a group of scumbags walking down ready to kill. Or even any of the doors a scumbag could pop out for a surprise attack. Let alone the fact this is all taking place in the interiors of an apartment building so there really aren't many places or space to really run or hide.But of course the best thing about the film is the action. There are a lot of memorable action sequences all superb choreographed and executed. Iko Uwais as Rama I think is a talented martial artist, I really love it when he executes some Mui Tai punching elbow combos he has some of the fastest hands and arms I've seen. I even like the gore effects in some places their practical and there are plenty of creative kills, my favorite is when Rama smashes the head of one scumbag on a wall about six times. And of course the battles themselves like one which is in some hallway and there are scumbags just popping out left and right charging toward Rama he just makes really quick work out of them with his knife and baton, just seeing him use the weapons and the techniques and combos he executes is awesome. But of course my favorite is the the two on one battle which is one of my favorite fights ever.The Raid has plenty of room for excitement.Rating: 4 stars

Every action movie needs a hero, and in The Raid, it is Rama(Iko Uwais) who at the beginning is seen doing pull ups, sit ups and punching a bag all in an early morning work out before waking his pregnant wife before leaving for work; which will not be a nine to five job at a desk. He is next inside an armored truck with fellow heavily armed SWAT team members, on their way to a building controlled by a powerful mobster. Once they gain entry, all hell breaks loose.As the team advances floor by floor, they encounter residents with automatic rifles, and are killed off like fish in a bowl, except for the leader and two other cops, including Rama, who exhibits Bruce Lee style fighting skills, repeatedly in several well done battles. We know that it will lead up to a final confrontation with the best opponent at the end. The violence is over the top and the story fairly typical, with competent acting and good camera work. I don't agree with the 8+ rating here, but I will give it a 7.

This Indonesian martial arts action movie should get much more attention it has obtained so far, although subtitles or dubbing do naturally decrease the audience in many countries. The director and screenwriter Gareth Evans (Welsh, but residing in Indonesia) has giftedly created a plot where violence, action and bursts are naturally within - a special police squad arrive at an apartment block in Jakarta's slums run by a hard crime and drug lord, with most of residents depending on or protected by him. In such a way, an exciting and memorable movie can begin without a long introduction and without the need for show other places of action but this building.Fights are fast and visually alluring: but so is this traditional martial art called pencak silat. As the main actor Iko Uwais (young officer Rama) has won National Silat Championship, it is no wonder... And he can really act, more than early Steven Seagal or Michael Dudikoff, for example. The other fighting talent is Yayan Ruhian as Mad Dog.Thus, if you like martial arts, intensive scenes and violence without playful undertone, this movie is definitely for you!

"The Raid: Redemption" is an overlong, uninvolving kung-fu/shoot'em up movie from Indonesia. It has the beginnings of a great good guy and a great villain, but fails to imbue them with any personality, to say nothing of the rest of the characters. It's like a long video game cut scene.I re-watched it recently, hoping to get what the fuss was about. I couldn't remember anything about it except that it was entirely set in a building with gangsters versus a SWAT team. I couldn't remember any characters or situations, and that wasn't my memory's fault: there are none to remember.The movie does have a few moments of invigorating martial arts, but when you consider the movie is 99% action, that's not a good ratio. I am not someone who believes things like plot and characters are unnecessary in an action movie. They can compliment each other, as they do in kung-fu classics like "Come Drink With Me" and "The Prodigal Son". "The Raid" is just a confusing mess of punching, kicking, stabbing, bashing, smashing, hacking, slashing, shooting, falling, and explosions. In this mural of violence, not one thing differentiates itself from anything else, or gives you any reason to care.

Review title: It's bloody, it's fun and it's bloody fun!
Review_body: After premiering at the Toronto Film Festival The Raid was hyped up as one of the best action film in a decade. With that hype behind it there was a risk it could have disappointed, but it did not. The Raid is a very entertaining action film that will please fans of Tony Jaa, Bruce Lee and martial arts films in general. Like The Avengers it made of impressive action scenes followed by impressive scenes, the highlight being the hallway fight with Iko Uwais stabbing his way through the badguys. Uwais is a great martial artist but he is not made out to be superhero, people can hit him, he can feel paid and Yayan Ruhian too is also a very talented fighter. The action is bloody and brutal, but director Gareth Edwards not linger or enjoy pain: he gets the right balance to satisfy our blood lush. Edwards uses an instant hand-held style that lets you feel the frenzy of the fights and action, but the fights themselves well shot, well edited and you can tell what is happening in the film. There is no need for shaky cam. At times the film plays like a survival horror with the criminals coming at the police like zombies, stabbing through walls like a slasher villain or jumping out apartments like in the Resident Evil games. The Raid also plays like the Warriors as gangs hunt our heroes for a main guy. The Raid is an entertaining film.

Review title: "The Raid: Redemption" - 30 Stories of Sheer, Bloody Adventure!
Review_body: In writer-director Gareth Evans's 2011 Indonesian action flick "The Raid: Redemption," only about 10 minutes of the entire picture is spent developing the film's plot before it's all-out, literally non-stop wall-to-wall action sequences. There's a little something early in the beginning about a Jakarta SWAT team being sent to a 30-story apartment building to fish out a sadistic drug lord named Tama Riyadi (Ray Sahetapy), who rules this crime-ridden tenement with an iron fist.As could be expected, although things start out well as the team slowly but assuredly takes over the building floor by floor, all hell breaks loose once they reach the sixth floor - it must be their (un)lucky number."The Raid: Redemption" is an astonishing martial arts-action thriller with plenty of sequences of hard-hitting, bone-crunching, bone-breaking action to keep your mouth watery; like most martial arts movies coming out of Southeast Asia these days, the actors look and sound like they're really going at it in full-contact, and it really looks and sounds like they're really getting hurt, too. Using elaborate martial arts choreography featuring the Indonesian fighting art Silat (plus borrowing a page or two from the Tony Jaa school of hard-knock fighting) and combining some of the most valuable elements from American action movies such as "Die Hard" (1988), "Assault on Precinct 13" (1976), "The Rock" (1996) and "The Warriors" (1979) plus Takashi Miike's samurai bloodbath "13 Assassins" (2010), "The Raid: Redemption" tells an exotic, self-contained story of fighting men fighting for survival.It's another pristine example of Asian action cinema done right that may have something in it for those primarily accustomed to Hollywood action flicks (if they look hard enough). While the movie does contain your usual intensely bloody shootouts and foot-chases down darkened apartment building corridors, the main focus is on the unarmed, closed-quarters combat fighting sequences, which there are way more of than gratuitous gun battles and are shot with such energized, bloody gusto that you honestly can't help but feel every single blow delivered - whether it be a good guy or a bad guy. Yes, once they lose their weapons, they have to punch, kick, and claw their way out of the 30th circle of Hell. After almost all the SWAT team members are nearly wiped out by Tama's thugs, it's up to a young SWAT officer named Rama (Iko Uwais, from Evans's earlier cult film "Merantau," which I haven't seen) to get his remaining teammates out alive and to safety.Pretty much in all of Rama's many, many hand-to-hand combat confrontations with both armed and unarmed thugs, anything and everything goes. Additionally, anything and everything available (and within reach) becomes a weapon - hammers, garrotes, machetes, axes, propane tanks, police batons, knives, broken fluorescent tubing, and the occasional splintered door. It's all really stunning stuff to witness on the screen, and Iko Uwais - also the film's co-fight choreographer - is more than capable of holding his own against a legion of bloodthirsty criminals, while also taking punishment of his own from all sides from his attackers. That's really the key to any action hero, in my opinion - to have a hero who can indeed kick a lot of a**, but also be able to take a few licks of his own and keep on ticking. It also helps that Rama has a pregnant wife back at home, so it makes him a bit more human and vulnerable and gives him an extra incentive to want to survive - and it also gives us an extra incentive to want to see him live through this ordeal.It's all amazingly bloody stuff to witness when you see the horrible things that humans are capable of doing to one another with just their bare hands. There are also several quieter, suspense-filled scenes as well, the most nerve-wracking of which being a scene where Rama and a severely wounded colleague hide behind a fake wall while an assailant repeatedly thrusts his machete through it, the blade barely missing Rama and his comrade. And also there's a wonderful electronic score on the American version of the film by Linkin Park's Mike Shinoda and Joe Trapanese to further fuel the adrenalin-laced plot and action sequences."The Raid: Redemption" is a richly served-up action flick from one of the last places to appear on the world action movie market - Indonesia (even though Gareth Evans is Welsh). Throw out everything you thought you knew about well-made action movies (from anywhere, really), and witness first-hand "The Raid: Redemption."10/10

Hard-hitting martial arts mayhem with as little actual storytelling as possible. We get a white knight, a villainous mastermind, a couple turncoats and a large, loud gang of dispensable supporting characters. Everybody plays their traditional roles; butts are kicked, scenery is smashed, lines are crossed and credits are rolled.It's as close to straight-up video game action as I've ever seen on the silver screen, particularly if you're one of those gamers who likes to skip the cutscenes. The fights are, generally, good enough to carry the picture single-handedly. They're intense and climactic, from the manic four-on-one rumble that kicks off the pandemonium to the nigh-invincible boss battle that concludes it. There's a jarring sense of harsh finality to The Raid, with a steady stream of weaponry in play and every duel culminating in a killing or crippling blow. There's no limping off, bruised ribs in-hand, to fight another day... these guys are visibly finished.In lieu of a deeper, less generic plot, it's that brutal efficiency which gives the film its identity. In six months' time, when I reflect on this film, that's what I'll remember. Not the flimsy double-turn pulled near the end, but the cleverly dismembered enemy combatants our hero has (sometimes literally) folded in half during his nonstop fifteen-floor rampage.

It's probably true to say that watching this Indonesian film will leave you exhausted. The story of a raid on a notorious drug gang's safe house is exhilarating, non-stop and relentless.The story itself is straightforward, but then it needn't be anything else. You have one set of characters that form the ruthless SWAT team, and another set of characters that make up an even more ruthless gang. That's all you need.The choreography is extraordinary. The actors went through a special training regime in order to study various combat protocols and weapons use. The result is a little too heavy to be labelled as fun, and too grisly to appeal to everyone; but it is an edge-of-your seat ride that rarely lets up for a moment, and I thoroughly recommend it. 8 out of 10.

Review title: Takes martial arts to the next level
Review_body: ¨Pulling a trigger is like ordering a takeout.¨The Raid Redemption has gotten so many great reviews that I decided to check it out despite never having heard anything about it. I had never seen an Indonesian film before, heard of director Gareth Evans, nor star actor Iko Uwais, but I was tempted to see it after hearing it won the People's Choice Award at the Toronto Film Festival. At first I really thought this movie was just another Battle Los Angeles where we had nonstop action with over the top gunfights. I'm not really a fan of these movies which only focus on the action and have little plot, but I was really in for a surprise with The Raid. Once the gunfights stopped, the combat became more ferocious involving a lot of knives, machetes, and even hand to hand combat. I've seen a lot of martial art movies before, but this film really set the bar with all those choreographed fights. They were truly amazing and I really enjoyed the last hour of the movie. The Raid is an extremely violent film so it isn't for everyone, but if you enjoy martial arts then you will love this film. Iko Uwais makes any other martial artist look silly as he is really impressive on screen, but so was the rest of the cast. The martial art used in this film is the traditional Indonesian one called Pencak Silat and it's intense. Iko Uwais choreographed the fights himself along with another actor who had some great fighting scenes, Yayan Ruhian. Together they make the film worth watching even though it has very little dialogue or story. There's no time for talking, it's one fist fight after another.Rama (Iko Uwais) is a rookie SWAT officer who seems happily married along with his pregnant wife. We only see them together in the opening scene where Rama kisses them goodbye before going to work. He gets on the SWAT car along with twenty other elite officers led by Sergeant Jaka (Joe Taslim) and are given instructions: They have to infiltrate and raid an apartment building in the middle of an Indonesian slum full of gangsters and drug dealers. Their mission is to capture the crime lord Tama (Ray Sahetapy), but it won't be an easy task because the building is full of loyal free renters who will protect him at all cost. That is why the police force has never attempted to go near that building, but somehow Lieutenant Wahyu (Pierre Gruno) has ordered the raid and is waiting for them near the entrance of the building. Once the SWAT team breaks in, some local spotters warn Tama that the police have entered the building. Tama observes everything through cameras in the top floor and announces to the entire building that whoever kills these officers will be given special treatment. He even sends his two personal bodyguards, Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian) and Andi (Donny Alamsyah), after them. The SWAT team find themselves ambushed between the sixth and seventh floor with nowhere to run. That is where the action begins and doesn't stop as all these renters keep on showing up while the officers fight for their lives.The plot is really simple, but believe me the choreographed action scenes are really not. That is what truly makes the movie for me: the hand on hand fighting scenes, especially those involving Iko Uwais and Yayan Ruhian. They are a true spectacle. I had never seen a martial art film like this before with so much intensity and carried out for such a long time. The final hour is practically nonstop action. I would never in a million years expect to have enjoyed a film like this, but the fighting scenes were so incredible that I was willing to forgive the poor plot and just enjoy the choreographed martial art scenes. I hear a sequel is in the making, and I am sure I will be watching it to see what else Iko Uwais has in store for us. This isn't a movie I would recommend to everyone, but if you like a good choreographed action movie then this is the film you will want to see because it truly does raise the bar for martial art films everywhere.http://estebueno10.blogspot.com

The Raid Redemption is an action movie directed by Gareth Evans and stars Iko Uwais, Joe Taslim, Ray Sahetapy, Yayan Ruhian, Donny Alamsyah and Pierre Gruno.This is what you call a pure action movie, lots of bullets, lots of fist fights, lots of super fast paced action scenes, lots of Violence, gore and blood. If you go into the script of the movie you'll find none but when you'll come to the action scenes of the movie you will find the movie spellbinding.The movie start on a positive note and after just 20 minutes of the start of the movie you'll understand that you are going to witness a pure joyride filled with action scenes, though being an action movie the gun fights is there but no usage of explosions, bombs and grenades and what you'll witness is fighting with knives, swords, punch to punch, fist to fist and hand to hand.The screenplay of the movie is very fast paced and keeps you engaged throughout, there are very less to minimal dialogues in the movie hence you can expect the amount of action scenes you are going to witness in the movie. The climax of the movie is somewhat disappointing and you'll feel the movie incomplete.There was not much scope for the acting and you'll understand this after watching the movie. But the action scenes in the movie is very superbly choreographed.This movie is a pure fast paced action movie and will keep you engaged throughout. If you are a action movie lover then this is the movie for you. A must must watch.

A thunder of a movie where I passed 80% of its runtime with my mouth open, eyes wide and electrified, scrolling back and forth through the tremendous martial-arts action scenes, repeatedly mesmerized by the prowesses.It is very well-acted (Iko Uwais - the best protagonist among others), superbly choreographed & edited, comes with awesome camera work & shots, with viewers basically "feeling" the full blow of bullets and hand-to-hand combats. The skinny devil antagonist was probably the best out of the herd with blinding techniques and his body connected to a power station!A way underrated movie, one of the best out there in terms of martial arts techniques & choreography combined with a smooth forceful flow like an engorged spring river. Some cliche and cheesiness are scattered throughout which absolutely doesn't ruin the amazing sensations that this movie provides.Highly recommended to lovers of crazy action martial arts thrillers who haven't seen this Indonesian gem yet!Screenplay/story: 7Direction/development: 9Realism: 9.2Entertainment: 9.4Acting: 8.5Cinematography/filming: 9Visuals/special effects: 9.4Music/score: 9.1Depth: 7Logic: 7Flow: 9.4Action/thrill: 9.6Ending: 7.

Review title: ABSOLUTELY BRILLIANT & PROBABLY THE BEST ACTION MOVIE EVER MADE!!! THE BEST FIGHT SCENES EVER IN ANY FILM...EVER
Review_body:
WOW!!! The Raid is full on frantic action-packed & exciting, probably the best Martial arts film ever & possibly the greatest action movie ever made!!!This gritty as hell, bone crunching cops vs criminals action Thriller is mind blowing with it's in your face fighting & brutal action.
This is Adrenaline-fuelled violence with stabbings & shootings all around in a grungy criminal infested Tower block of danger!!!
I can totally see where the BRILLIANT Dredd got it's setting from.This has the best fighting scenes I've ever seen in any movie ever!!!
This also is also actually scary with it's intense situation & savage Machete wielding bad guys, the whole situation of a team of cops going to raid a crime lords huge apartment block that's full of enemies is so exciting & intense i absolutely loved every second of it!!!This is action cinema at it's absolute best, move over Expendables all you need is the fantastic warrior Iko Uwais, this guy is warrior who puts Jet Li & Jackie Chan to shame!!!
Iko is a good actor who uses his intense face to show what's happening & he's excellent but also equally great is his police team leader Joe Taslim, this guy can fight & has one of the best fights in the movie when he goes up against the evil unstoppable Mad Dog!!! Joe Taslim is very good intense looking actor & gives a hell of a good performance on screen & is one of the best characters, well he's side by side Iko Uwais.The Raid is a brutal Crime Thriller & an Action-packed Cop film featuring the greatest fight scenes in any movie ever that i have seen!!!
The camera angles captures every blow & stab it's outstanding film making thanks to the excellent director Gareth Evans.The setting of the tower block is an intense & scary place full of danger.The Raid is an action packed MASTERPIECE of action cinema!!!
It's Absolutely BRILLIANT.
A Powerhouse brutal crime Action Thriller & believe me it's Thrilling!!!

Review title: The best action movie of the last years
Review_body: This movie comes fresh and straight from Indonesia and pleases or displeases the viewers with many brutal killing scenes, some rough but technically well performed fights and a couple of breathtaking stunts at a full speed pace. This movie is surely nothing for soft-heartened people as there is a lot of blood in the film that one isn't used to from the Western cinema industry. It's also thanks to its radical execution that the movie surprisingly rose to international fame. People aren't looking for beautiful male actors, cool dialogues and romantic side stories anymore in action movies. This movie simply goes back to the simplistic basis with a rough kind of energy.The only modern touches this movie kept were two twists. Any movie of any genre seems to have the need to include at least one twist towards the end. I don't know why this trend degenerated but I think this tendency gets more and more overused. This movie contains one extremely predictable twist and another less predictable but still not impressive one. They desperately want the movie to get more depth and character development but the effect is the opposite.The movie itself takes no prisoners. We see the main actor praying and training for the first two minutes of the movie. The next three minutes are dedicated to a short introduction that explains what will happen during the next one hour and a half. A well trained but mostly unexperienced special unit police squad gets the suicidal task to infiltrate the fifteen floors of a dingy skyscraper in a rundown suburb of Jakarta's slums. The building has become a safe house for the city's most dangerous crooks. It's controlled by a very influential gangster boss and his two acolytes that represent the brain and the force to save, execute and extend their master's will. The squad tries to arrest as many villains as possible with the final goal being to arrest the big boss dead or alive on the final floor. The next circa ninety minutes show in dynamic camera angles with fast paced modern music a couple of tension filled hide and seek moments, a few more intriguing dialogues and mostly non-stop violence that portrays the tragic fate of twenty courageous good guys against hundreds of enemies. Not one second is wasted. This film will leave you out of breath. You may lose track of who people are, where people are and what they are exactly doing but it won't harm your (dis)pleasure about this movie.Now, what is so fascinating about a ninety minute long slaughter fest? What has made this movie's reputation? Is there more in this except of a pervertedly shocking violence? Yes, there is. First of all, there are the aesthetics. Every actor who played a member of the SWAT had to run through a hard training program to study the techniques used in the force including details such as hand signals. You can see this precise preparation in each second of the movie. The choreographic aspects are perfectly arranged, no matter if we see realistic martial arts sequences, fast stabbings or tension filled shooting passages from close and far.Second, many important characters have all something unique that makes the viewers feel against or with them. These trademarks can be seen in the moral or philosophical attitudes of the characters. You have the brutal fighter that refuses to simply shoot people as he prefers to fight his enemies from face to face and kill them with his bare hands. You have the peaceful outsider who risks his life to help some strangers because he has gone through hard times on is own before. You have a villain that has to make a tough decision between radical obedience, a smart putsch or a treason because of personal issues of his past. All these well developed characters will keep you on the edges of your seat until the end if you're not disgusted by the movie's brutality. As this movie is quite grounded without any big special effects makes the whole thing even more addicting, honest and real.Third, the movie has a lot of tension filled moments in between many breathtaking fight scenes. Suddenly, a killer slowly approaches the victims that are hiding behind the next or corner or behind a thin wall. Out of the blue, the lights shut down and the main villain starts to communicate with both his enemies and the building's ruthless residents. At another moment, the squad is all surrounded by villains and needs to find a fast, risky and smart solution to get out of this hell. There is always something happening in between fights and important dialogues.Normally, this movie would only get eight points from me because of its relative simplicity, its unnecessary twisted parts and the shallow ending. On the other side, this flick truly gave me a huge load of adrenaline and time passed by so fast that I deeply wanted to continue watching this. That's why I give it a little bonus point that I would rarely give. It doesn't happen quite often but this time I agree with critics and fans. This is by far the best action movie made in the last years. Any genre fan that doesn't mind some brutal stuff should call this his or her new bible.Hollywood should get inspired by this. Skip useless side stories, forced twists and billion dollar special effects. Don't dishonour this exotic effort by doing a shallow remake. People are tired of these things and would like to see some innovation from Hollywood again after many bad years with sequels and remakes. People don't want to see a remake with Jason Statham as tough cop and Johnny Depp as the weird villain. If you want to pay some tribute, go and ask actors like Iko Uwais or Yayan Ruhian to join "The Expandables III". Encourage the originals and the talented Asian cinema.

An inexperienced SWAT team is on a mission to raid a building housing some scary mobster and his goons. Early on we learn that there may be some other motives behind the orders given by the lieutenant. Things go well as they make it up to floor 6. Then they are discovered. What follows is a good half an hour of exhilarating shoot-out/fistfight scenes in which the inexperience will cost the team dearly. Bodies fly all over the place like sacks of potatoes and there are plenty of mean ways of killing.As we get to know some of the characters involved- some good-natured cops, one of whom is related to one of the mobster's captains- suddenly the movie becomes a wild and remarkable martial arts movie as hordes of goons attack the few surviving cops. The movie loses steam at some point but manages to pick it up again as the meanest of the captains is also almost unbeatable in his martial arts skill. The movie doesn't shy away from unfair fights. The mean captain is a tiny tiny guy but he isn't afraid to take on two guys at the same time.The Raid is an outstanding action movie. It is polished and exceptionally well directed. But when it comes to the action, it sticks to proved basics. There isn't lighting trickery, booming sound effects, supernatural wire-work- just lightning fast punches and kicks, and millions of bullets. And these punches hurt, this aren't the gentle ones found in the Matrix trilogy. One just has to see the long list of health care professionals listed in the credits. The story is rather thin and the production doesn't make enough use of it. I think more could have been done with the story. I found the police action shootouts superior to the martial arts action. You do become exhausted of the martial arts fights eventually. The Raid is to Indonesia what Ong-Bak was to Thailand, it could put Indonesia on the map for action movies. Hopefully they'll take advantage of it. Kudos to the entire cast and the director who turned what could have been an average movie into something unforgettable.

Review title: One of the best action movies
Review_body: The Raid is one of the best action movies ever with a simple and effective premise that's extremely intense and thrilling throughout. Iko Uwais gives an incredibly committed lead performance and Donny Alamsyah and Yayan Ruhian are both great. Gareth Evans' direction is amazing and it's superbly filmed with visceral and breathtaking action sequences. It's expertly paced and the music by Mike Shinoda and Joe Trapanese is excellent.

Review title: No plot, ALL ACTION! And the best action you will have seen in years!
Review_body: Mayhem, senseless violence, and martial arts carnage like you can't imagine, but in a good way :) . The martial arts sequences are fast and brutal in a way that reminded me of the ultra-violent 1970s Sonny Chiba martial arts films and also made me feel as I did the first time I saw "Ong-bak," where a tired martial arts formula had new life breathed into it. Iko Uwais ("Man of Tai Chi" "Beyond Skyline") leads a group of South Korean cops on a drug raid at an apartment building only to find themselves trapped and under siege from the residents who are controlled by the kingpin living on the top floor. The cops must fight their way up to the top floor, facing wave after wave of increasingly difficult opponents. The story is little more than an excuse to go from one action set piece to the next, but that's not always a bad thing (i.e. Walter Hill's "The Warriors" is one long chase but is an unabashed classic). While, "The Raid: Redemption" is definitely not for all tastes and despite it's many weak points (plot, character development, acting, etc.), it's essential viewing for all martial arts fans and will blow your socks off!

Review title: Simple and effective. An action movie with focus.
Review_body: I've heard about this movie since it was released, especially in relation to its shockingly similar plot to Dredd. All I had heard about it was the awesome action.And that's what I got: a simple plot and awesome action.The story is of a group of police officers tasked with taking a high rise from a drug lord, and they have to fight their way up and then back down. Their plan to sneak up gets shot, and action takes over. Bullets quickly run out, and everyone rips out their martial arts skills (which are surprisingly uniform). It's thin, but fun, much like John Wick, which is also built on a simple premise and then delivers well-executed action for its relatively short running time.I enjoyed what I got, but it felt like the steps necessary to make the movie better would have been easy enough to take. There are a pair of brothers on both sides, one police officer and the other a lieutenant to the drug lord, but the mere existence of the relationship isn't revealed until about halfway through the movie and even then, the dialogue leaves the audience guessing for a good part of the conversation what is actually going on. There's also an information dump towards the end about the nefarious reasons that the police lieutenant took the officers in without telling anyone else about it. It's not that the reasons themselves are poor (they make a good bit of sense), it's that it all comes out in the last five minutes. We've known that the police lieutenant is bad news for a while, which is really all we need, so if the actual reasons are going to come out, don't end your pulse-pounding action movie with two people talking about it for several minutes at the end.I wrote more about my problems with the movie than what I liked, but that's because what I liked was really simple and most of the movie, and what I didn't just required a bit more explanation. The movie really is quite a bit of fun. It's grungy and rather brutal in its violence, and the chaos is very well managed from beginning to end. I just wish that the plot outside the main action (the lieutenant's nefarious reasons) had been handled more evenly and that the brothers stuff had been more central to the actual story and, again, handled more evenly.

A freaking masterpiece. 
The greatest action film ever made, seriously. Elite cops vs a building full of guys with guns, knives, machetes and a very mad dog. This must have been my third time watching it. I didn't even hunt it down, came on TV and I had to watch it AND right after watching it I had to hunt down the sequel and watch that too. This is a must watch for any action junkie.

I can imagine action filmmakers just sitting around and getting tired of the criticisms about lack of plot. So Gareth Evans decided to give us The Raid. Cops go in to get a crimelord, they end up trapped, lots of fighting and shooting. The film puts fights and choreography before everything else and it is to its credit. Iko Uwais is an action sensation and also knows how to emote using his facial expressions. The fights flow lyrically and Evans always knows where to place the camera. No shaky camera business here. At times the fights did feel too controlled. I kept thinking to my self that I could have a few of these guys in a fight as I would have no qualms with punching their nuts. I know it's a silly nitpick, but the amount of exposed crotches would have lead to shorter fights. Not that I wanted this, but there are no rules when fighting for your life. The violence is well handled and it truly adds to the desperation of the situation, it doesn't try to gross you out but it does want you to feel the shots, stabbings, and punches. Evans also knows to give us a bit of a breather so we can appreciate those action scenes more. There are also a few "how did they do that" moments, which are getting rarer and rarer these days. Yes I wish I had felt more connected to these characters, but for the adrenaline rush it is, it's wonderful.

Insanely good film coming out of Indonisia. 'The Raid' is one of the best action movies ever made (if not the greatest) and for once you can trust the blurb on the poster. If this film was an English language speaking picture it would be as famous as 'Die Hard' but 5 million times better. Introducing a new martial arts sensation Iko Uwais (playing a rookie cop). Just only seven years old and already regarded as a classic of its type. Only rivaled by Tony Jaa in the 'Ongbak' series and the totally mad 'The Raid 2'. Imagine 'Mad Max 2', in a single Tower Block.

So let me start off by saying the action is pretty much non-stop. It's not quite the level of Transformers Dark of the Moon, but it is pretty intense.The martial arts and fight choreography are pretty good and you never doubt that any of the people (except maybe the old white-haired guy) would be able to hold their own in an actual fight. In short, fairly believable.I say fairly because at times the action just goes on TOO long. As with so many Asian martial arts flicks this one occasionally suffers from the "indestructible fighters" syndrome. Fights drag on for ages in some cases, far beyond what any person, even ridiculously fit ones, would be capable of sustaining.The whole thing has the ring of a video game. I'm not sure if it was intentional, or not. As an example, in the final battle, two fighters take on the main bad guy's henchman. The minute the scene was set for the fight I was thinking... "Ah! Final boss fight!" and I wasn't wrong.That fight went on for several loooong minutes. It actually became rather boring to watch, with repetitive moves and the aforementioned indestructible characters getting up again and again.At the end, when they finally beat the bad guy, my mind mentally overlaid an XBox-style achievement award, "Defeated the Boss's right-hand man - 50G".And that is the biggest problem with The Raid. There is little substance to the film other than combat and battles. There is little character development. All the imagination went into the fight sequences and it shows.It was also rather odd to realise that there appeared to be only two female characters in the film, both of whom are relegated to lying in beds and doing nothing for the duration of their very limited screen time.Anyway, it is worth watching for the fighting, if you like that sort of thing. Just don't expect much in the way of a deep plot or characterisations.

Review title: Vertiginous, next-level, glass-ceiling annihilating, action-movie ultra-violence!
Review_body: A triumphantly talented taffy overloads the thrill-starved hearts and minds of fight-fevered Action-Jackson loving junkies the world over with his deliriously dynamic, dynamite-deadly, death-dealing, bone-crushing, bullet-shredding, concrete-crushing ascent into vertiginous, next-level, glass-ceiling annihilating, action-movie ultra-violence! Pure, hyper-adrenalized, serotonin-slathered, pulse-pounding pugilistic pleasure right from the savage, sinew-snapping start to fatally ferocious, face-ripping finish! Gareth Evan's adamantine 'The Raid' makes that ceaselessly self-aggrandizing twaddle of soft lad Tarantino look like the diuretic drooling of a milk-soaked old maid!

Review title: THE RAID is Brutal and Unforgiving in it's Execution
Review_body: Sometimes, when you want a good solid action movie, you need to steer clear of Hollywood (and their current trend of PG-13, sugar-coated, spastically edited clones) and direct your attention to the other side of the world. In this case, Indonesia. From rising Welsh filmmaker Gareth Evans, THE RAID is a non-stop bloody explosion of martial arts awesomeness. This movie makes no apologies for what it is: a hardcore action film with a massive body count and cringe-inducing kills, with a bit of plot thrown in for flavor. THE RAID is less a movie and more a showcase for talented stuntmen and martial artists and brought together by a man with a passion for the genre. The premise for the movie is simple: Tama is a drug baron is holed up on the fifteenth floor of an apartment building where he oversees his empire, filling the building with junkies and thugs loyal to the cause. He's considered near untouchable, hidden in his fortress with aid from his adviser Andi and a vicious psychopath (referred to as Mad Dogfor a reason). A SWAT unit finds themselves in the precarious position when assigned to bring Tama to justice. We follow rookie officer Rama, one of 20 officers assigned to the mission, as the building is raided and everything turns disastrous when a spotter sounds the alarm. With every thug in the building on the attack and his thoughts returning to his pregnant wife at home, Rama and his surviving fellow officers must survive the assault when they're trapped in the chaos without reinforcements.While, normally, I'd condemn the average mindless Hollywood action schlock, THE RAID gets a special pass for getting right what most American action films get wrong. There is an established plot in the film; it's thin, but it's there. A handful of cops are trapped in an apartment building surrounded by murderous lowlifes and must survive. Once the context is established, THE RAID is all about the action. From about 25 minutes into the film until the very end, this movie is non-stop action, with one sequence transitioning to another with a handful of exposition moments tossed in the middle to keep the story moving. Evans is a longtime fan of the martial arts genre and proves he has a talent for putting action on film. He keeps the camera angles wider so we can witness a lot more of the action, whereas a lot of American action films keep the camera in tight, with fast-moving cuts that often keep the action confusing and disorienting. Evans wants none of that and he shows us every punch, kick, stabbing, etc. The fights are fast and brutal and, more importantly, bloody. None of this bloodless violence we're becoming more and more accustomed to in American action. When people are hit with bullets, knives, machetes, whateverwe see the damage and we feel the impact. It's intense and it makes for some of the coolest fight sequences I've seen in recent years. It's not chockfull of special effects (and those that are utilized are not blatant) and glossed over; it's a handful of talented martial artists and some great choreography.You have to be a bit more open-minded to enjoy THE RAID. The movie is in Indonesian, so I hope you don't mind subtitles or voice dubbing. Another "detriment" to general audiences is a complete lack of recognizable faces in the roles. Evans cast the film with Indonesian martial artists, some of which have never even been in a movie before. Iko Uwais (Rama, the main character) is a Silat specialist (Silat = an Indonesian form of martial arts) who has currently only ever been in two filmsTHE RAID and Evan's smaller first film MERENTAU. You'd never know that he's not a trained actor as he nails his performance in the movie, regardless of his fighting skills. He's sympathetic in his role as Rama with his sense of honor in his job and his unwavering confidence. The same with Yayan Ruhian as Mad Dog, a stuntman and fight choreographer that Evans enlisted as the insane henchman with an insatiable bloodlust. Mad Dog is the coolest character in the movie (despite beingyou knowevil) with a cold- blooded nature and a hint of humor in Ruhian's performance. Overall, THE RAID is a killer action movie that's big on bloody violence and, while short on plot or exposition, accomplishes it's mission of thrilling it's audience with an mind-blowing display of martial arts talent thanks to a passionate director behind the scenes.

Review title: A must-see for all action junkies, this is the quintessential martial-arts movie, packed wall-to-wall with no-holds-barred thrills and exhilarating real-life stunts
Review_body: Just when the Asian martial-arts genre had lost one of its brightest young stars Tony Jaa to mysticism, along comes Indonesian actor Iko Uwais to give it a renewed kick of life- and boy let's just say that it is not simply a kick, but more accurately a lightning jolt. Fans of the genre shouldn't be all too surprised at the hype surrounding 'The Raid: Redemption', the second collaboration between Iko and Welsh-born director Gareth Evans- their first Merantau' already offered a peek at what the 31-year-old 'silat' practitioner was capable of.Learning from the lessons of their earlier film, Gareth has pared down the elements of plot, character, dialogue and perhaps most importantly culture specificity to deliver a quintessential action film that riffs on Hollywood classics like 'Die Hard' and 'Assault on Precinct 13'. So the premise is kept simple but yet efficient- an elite special forces team is ordered to raid a grimy tenement building that has long been the stronghold of a powerful drug kingpin Tama (Ray Sahetapy).Uwais' character Rama is one of the police officers sent into the suicide mission, introduced with a tersely told prologue that sees him kissing his pregnant wife goodbye and telling his father that he will 'bring home' his presumably lost brother. Gareth, who also wrote the screenplay, uses the former insofar as motivation for Rama to keep fighting and reserves the latter for a somewhat unexpected plot twist that gives the film more depth than you would expect.Otherwise, he keeps his focus on the setup for the action sequences which are unequivocally the purpose of the entire movie. Right from the start, we are left in anticipation for that climactic fight between Rama and Tama's two henchmen Andi (Doni Alamsyah) and Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian), the latter of whom is described by the team leader (former Indonesian judo champion Joe Taslim) as 'a maniac of feet and fists that would tear down walls for his boss'. That doesn't mean however that Gareth, who co- choreographed the action with Yayan and Iko himself, takes it easy in the meantime.Rather, he unleashes all the bullets at his disposal within the first half-hour, as the team finds themselves up and against every lowlife tenant in the building, promised free rent by Tama if they can rid the building of its recent 'cockroach infestation'. What's worse, the building is rigged with cameras at every corner and on every floor which Tama views from the safety of his control room right up on the fifteenth storey- and suffice to say it isn't long before the whole team is whittled down to just Rama, his team leader and their corrupt boss Lt. Wahyu (Pierre Gruno).No matter really- simplicity is still ultimately the beauty of this no- holds-barred action movie so the faster we get to the good guys that matter the better. To up the ante, our heroes are clearly outnumbered as they are set upon floor by floor by thugs wielding knives, guns and machetes. Even though these earlier fights are just appetisers for the main showdown, it is evident that no lack of effort has been made to ensure that each is gripping to the bone.Amidst snapped necks, smashed skulls and slit throats, the singular thing that impresses is the thrilling efficiency by which Iko dispatches his opponents. There is nothing too elaborate that the killings appear contrived; rather, brutal as they may be, Iko keeps them realistic and most of all inventive, coming up with new ways each time round to ensure that the brawls are always never less than captivating. Kudos to Iko for both his choreography and execution, both of which combine to emphasise the artistic aspect in the martial-arts form on display.In contrast to Iko's Rama, there is something elementally frightening about Yahan's Mad Dog, who in an extended sequence sure to make the squeamish wince, uses his plain fisticuffs to beat one of the police officers to his death instead of ending it quickly with his pistol. "This is what I do," he says, holding up his hands- so formidable is he that when Rama eventually takes him on, it becomes a two-against-one battle with the odds in the latter's favour.That finale, taking place inside the confines of an iron-walled room, is one of the most exhilarating and exhausting fight scenes ever captured on film, capped with a satisfyingly violent finish that had the audience at this reviewer's screening clapping their hands in glee. And the best part about it is that you get to see every move in the clarity it deserves, both lensers- Matt Flannery and Dimas Imam Subhono- constantly offering fresh new angles to the action and vehemently eschewing the kind of shaky-cam or quick editing Hollywood is too fond of employing nowadays.Complemented with a pulsating score by Joseph Trapanese and Linkin Park's Mike Shinoda, there is no doubt this exceptional film deserves all the positive buzz that has come its way since premiering to raves at the Toronto International Film Festival. It is relentlessly breathtaking every step of the way, building tension and excitement minute by minute until it unleashes its ultimate salvo guaranteed to leave you cheering. Under the assured hands of director Gareth Evans, who despite his young age has mastered a skillful grasp on the action genre, 'The Raid: Redemption' is also sure to be a star-making vehicle for Iko- and if you can't quite figure out why there is the word 'redemption' in its title, then take it simply for the fact that it has brought due recognition to the dazzling partnership between Iko and Gareth after the under- appreciated 'Merantau'.www.moviexclusive.com

Directed by Gareth Edwards. Iko Uwais, Donny Alamsyah, Joe Taslim, Ray Sahetapy, Pierre Gruno, Yayan Ruhian, Iang Darmawan, Alfridys Godfred, Tegar Satrya. (R)A Jakartan SWAT team infiltrates a dilapidated tenement ruled by a vicious druglord and his gang. That's about as far as "plot" goes, and character development arguably fares just as poorly; this movie is just a presentation of nearly non-stop violent action scenes. Suffers for its scant human interest--a couple of plot twists in the second half don't register at all since the affected characters have no dimension beyond "good" and "bad"--but there's no arguing that the movie does precisely what it intends to do: deliver a series of adrenaline jolts, make the audience squirm when the gore gets intense, and make them pump their fists when the bludgeons, bullets and blades hit their targets. Excellent fight choreography throughout, but the shaky-cam and occasionally choppy cuts do it no favors. Like "Dredd" (which was released later that year and uses a very similar set-up), it will be very appealing to action/martial arts fanatics, but the cumulative experience rings a bit hollow. Given the subtitle "Redemption" for its US release to avoid a rights violation.72/100

Review title: Non-stop action doesn't make up for lack of suspense, some cool moments aside.
Review_body: The Raid is swiftly getting a reputation as one of the best action movies ever. Apparently featuring non-stop creative action like we've never seen before, I was intrigued, even if it really wasn't my type of film at all. Fortunately, I guess it isn't much like a video game as I expected but it's much more of a mess. There's some interesting set pieces and they do play with them well, but it's a very uninteresting seedy universe with its saturated faux-grit in the colour grading. I've never been a fan of martial arts movies and after the first half has tedious gunplay, it moves onto kung fu which I don't find particularly engaging. The little story it does have is what makes it interesting, they should have focused on it a little more as I was confused in the end as to what happened. It does have a few cathartic moments where it is creative but otherwise it looks like an average film to me. The dubstep soundtrack doesn't help.6/10

This one of the Indonesian film at its finest. Most actions are part of its grimy yet dark storyline fitted with claustrophobic perspective of main characters encountering many of their enemies within the plot places. The characters on the film are cared to its story and its action that makes you feel entertained while watching this film. While many parts of the film including the gun sound is fully CGI and the weapons itselves are artificial props its relieved by its outstanding Silat martial arts choreography thanks to Iko Uwais and Yayan Ruhian

Review title: This movie is the mother of all modern action films.
Review_body: Indonesian special tactics officer Rama prays, practices silat and bids goodbye to his father and wife, who is pregnant with his child. He cryptically promises his father he will "bring him home." Rama joins a heavily armed 20-man elite police squad, including Officers Bowo and Dagu, Sergeant Jaka, and Lieutenant Wahyu, for a raid on a high-rise apartment block in Jakarta's slums. The team intends to capture crime lord Tama Riyadi, who, along with his two lieutenants Andi and Mad Dog, owns the block and lets criminals and junkies around the city rent rooms under his protection. Arriving undetected, the team sweeps the first floors and subdues various criminal tenants; they also temporarily detain an innocent, law-abiding tenant delivering medicine to his sick wife in apartment #726. Continuing undetected to the sixth floor, the team is spotted by a young lookout, who passes on the message to another adolescent lookout just before he is shot dead by Lt. Wahyu; the latter youth raises the alarm.

Serbuan Maut - The Raid: Redemption – CATCH IT (B+) Ever since The Raid premiered on various festivals all over the world. The buzz surrounding the movie was increasing day by day. Finally now I got the chance to see Malaysian blockbuster The Raid: Redemption. This is a story of a SWAT team becomes trapped in a tenement run by a ruthless mobster and his army of killers and thugs. The main protagonist of the movie is defiantly its brutal and fast tempo action. Where other movies have a strong story and dialogues, the raid covers those things with brutal action. The action sequences of the movie are so well choreographed and shot that not for a second you feel like it's getting too much. There are many moments which will literally makes you jump of your seat. The performance by all the actors is good considering the genre. In the end, it's a highly entertaining movie and even non action/violence lovers will enjoy the movie immensely.

Review title: Wow... the action in this film was mind blowing!
Review_body:
This is no doubt one of the greatest action movies I have ever seen. This is a violent movie with very little dialogue so know that before going in. The hand to hand fighting in this film is the best to ever be put on the big screen. This movie seriously blew me away. The one flaw would be that it doesn't have the greatest plot but it's enough to keep the action interesting. Please do yourself a favor and watch this movie!
..............................................................
THE RAID: REDEMPTION QUOTES
Let's clean this city's mess!

Review title: Electrifying action, stunning choreography -- great action movie
Review_body: Director and writer Gareth Evans shows his incredible gift of action filmmaking, demonstrating solid martial arts choreography, spectacular gun shootouts, and a stellar plot in this inventive Indoenisan action thriller. The Raid: Redemption follows the story of Lieutenant Wahyu who leads a S.W.A.T team of commandos on a no-holds-bar mission to raid a twenty-story apartment building in search of a vicious drug kingpin named Tama. Fighting through an army of gangsters. The team find themselves faced with overwhelming odds as they left fighting with limited ammunition and use of incredible Martial arts skills. This intense film features the cast of Iko Uwais, Joe Taslim, Donny Alamsyah, Ray Sahatapy, Yayan Ruhian, and many others.Action has been among one of my favorites genres in Hollywood. The action genre has come a long way with films like Die Hard, The Rock, Face/Off, The Matrix, The Bourne Identity, and the recent Mad Max: Fury Road. This foreign films is a rare action thriller that shows a textbook example of how action flicks should be done. The action sequences consisting of intense and bloody gun shootouts and electrifying martial arts fights are incredible and exciting to sit through. Baring some resemblance to the fight scenes in 'The Matrix', these scenes display some outstanding choreography, and the camera-work done by hand-held camera is quite striking as it captures the pure intensity of the scenes instead of bloating the action with ridiculous shaky cam that many action films suffer from. The final fight scene during the last fifteen minutes can easily be held as one of the greatest fight scenes ever put on screen. The plot also works pretty well and remains intriguing for most of (if not the whole) thanks to its powerful pacing. The character on the other hand, could use some improvement. Iko Uwais's character is decent and solidly written as well as Ray Sahatapy's character Tama, the drug lord who the SWAT team pursues after. The rest of the characters lack depth and little to nothing to known about them other them being elite SWAT members. The Raid: Redemption is one of the best action films I have seen in a long time, and a film every action fan must see. It is very fun and pulse-pounding to watch, and there is never a dull moment. However, the film is definitely not for the squeamish as it gets extremely violent and bloody from start to finish. This is best indicated by one of the film's tag lines "1 minute of romance, 99 minutes of non-stop carnage".

I'm not a connoisseur of martial arts films, but now and again I like to try one. 'Serbuan Maut' was hailed by many, so it was a logical choice. The fights and action in it are really quite amusing, the fight between the three guys in the end being the proverbial cherry on top.The makers tried to put in some decent story lines, but those hardly grabbed me at all, even if it is an okay way to balance things out a little, action- and drama-wise. And I'll skip discussing the credibility of certain actions altogether...The setting is grim and bleak: a supposedly enormous apartment building. Yet there is hardly any outside action to display this properly; there are mainly just inside (studio) settings of small corridors and rooms. That's too bad.I liked it, and I've had my wholesome portion of bloody ballet for a while, though in the future I think I will be going back in time to try an old Bruce Lee or a wuxia.A big 6 out of 10.

Review title: The Raid Redemption Review: Perhaps the best martial arts action film ever!
Review_body: Movie: The Raid Redemption (A): Action - Indonesian Positives:The film starts very well and soon after some time, the killer action takes the charge and goes on to entertain till the very last frame. The action scenes are extremely excellent and they were so well crafted that while watching the movie, I opened my mouth only to say "wow" at the best moves!The screenplay is very tight and the editing, razor sharp. It's not stretched at all and you won't even wish it to be shorter, especially if you're an action fan.Iko Uwais impresses big time and fits into the character of Rama. As soon as he comes into his action mode, claps and whistles are bound to make an appearance!The film has everything you would want a perfect action film to be.Plus, there isn't any vulgarity or obscenity as the focus is completely on the action and storytelling. Hats off to director Gareth Evans for that!Negatives:Nil.Repeat value: Absolutely!THE RAID REDEMPTION is undoubtedly the best martial arts action film ever. Actually, I had seen the sequel first and liked it a lot. But what makes this prequel better, despite of the sequel having some even better action sequences, is its complete devotion to action.

Review title: Perhaps the best martial arts film I've seen
Review_body: I'm probably going to sound like a little kid here but HOLY CRAP! Everything you have heard about this film is absolutely true. The fighting choreography in this is unlike anything I have ever seen. Now I might screw up some of the characters and their names here, but that's only because they are relatively unknown. Iko Uwais is the main actor in this and according to his bio on IMDb, he is a Taiwanese Silat champion and has been studying it since 10. It shows. His skill is eye popping, truly incredible. And then there's the main villain in the film, who I think is Mad Dog. He's played by some dude named Yahan Ruhian. He is just as impressive, if not more than Uwais. Another martial artist named Doni Alamsyah makes up a trifecta of gifted martial artists. The last battle is a three way as Uwais and Alamsyah team up to fight Ruhian. It truly left me breathless and I clapped in the empty theatre when it was done. I don't know how they did it, but if you think you have seen incredible martial arts battles before, this one will put it to shame.The story? Who cares. Crimelords in Jakarta trap a bunch of SWAT team members in a building and all freakin hell breaks loose. That's all that really has to be said because it is the choreography and the fights in the film that take centre stage and it's one of the best I've ever seen.This is one hell of a ride. 9/10

Review title: Good action movie, but slightly disappointing after all the hype
Review_body: As a martial artist and action movie fan, everyone I know told me I should watch this. And the raving reviews seemed to confirm it. So my expectations might have been a little too high. It is a very well done action movie with great fight scenes to be sure. But the absolute absence of pretense at a story is a bit disappointing; moreover, some aspects of the fight sequences were a bit lacking to be honest. Keep your expectations low and you might enjoy yourself.
This is a serious kick arse action action movie. Literally non stop action and great fighting scenes. Completely far fetched, over the top and zero plot, but great fun!!!

Violence has become a mainstream in modern movies, and I am not particularly happy about that. But films like the Raid give me hope.For one the movie as a whole is excellently orchestrated in the method of an SAS strike. It gets in, does the job and gets straight back out again. The film is a crisp 100 minutes long and doesn't waste time dilly dallying around with unnecessary sub plots. Saying that the film is not devoid of substance, the exact amount of back story to flesh the characters out has been included with surgical precision.The main star of the show is the action sequences. They are fast, brutal and visually impressive.I am not a massive fan of action films as I tend to get bored by the incessant beatings the lead role tends to endure. But I found this gripping all the way to the end.

Review title: No time for a story, but still FREAKING AWESOME!
Review_body: I often don't like brainless movies that are only action or technical prowess/special effects.For example: Mad Max Road whatever was impossible to watch. It was so boring as the longest chase escene ever.This is a similar concept, with no story, no arc, no nothing besides the action set pieces. And YET, they knew what they were doing and put a lot of heart on those little scenes where people talk to each other.Other than those mere minutes of dialogue and "story", the movie is an impossibly good set piece of martial art after the other and not a PG-13 version of it, so you would feel and see the punches. This is a very good movie overall, with a perfect runtime (contrary to the waay too long Mad Max), that does experctly what they wanted to do, put just enough heart, and its not a perfect ten, only because the "story" was still lacking. Even if the movie "doesn't need a story" because its about the action, the reality is that, it could've used a better one.One last thing. The score and sound effects/mixing was PERFECT. Often in this movies the sounds are super ultra loud for no reason, but here it was all balanced and my ears appreciated that. Also, the score is perfect too, as was the cinematography. Like I said, the technical parts of this movie were just perfect.

(69%) It is by far one the best martial arts movies I've ever seen with action set pieces and fights that drop your jaw. There's nothing quite like this as you really do feel every punch and kick. The scene in-which the team realise they have walked into a death trap is one of the all-time greats and the directer pulled of a miracle with the limited budget. My only minor complaint comes from the slightly overly oppressive setting and tone, but it does add to the feeling of going through hell and back just as the lead role, and although the violence can be strong it never feels like it has gone too far or is just trying to shock, this has too much going for it for that. This will movie will live on and become a future classic just as "Enter the dragon" did in the 1970's.

Review title: The Raid is Insane-- in a good way
Review_body: In "The Raid: Redemption" the awesome fight scene has brothers Rama (Iko Uwais) and Andi (Donny Alamsyah) trading punches, kicks, and locks with Mad Dog (badass Yayan Ruhian). The fight literally lasts 10 minutes. Rama and Andi are attacking Mad Dog simultaneously—none of this one at a time stuff. Director and writer Gareth Evans also shoots full body action sequences-- no quick cut edits of torso moves. Uwais is a master of Silat, Indonesian martial art, and really kicks some ass up to this point. But Mad Dog is unstoppable—a master perhaps jacked up on meth. The fight scene is insane, one of the best in movies ever. "The Raid" is awesome. As my bud Robert, a film director, pointed out that the production values are weak, and the narrative is thin. However, he also said that you see "The Raid" for the amazing martial arts.Set in Jakarta, Uwais plays Rama, who is a SWAT member and expectant father. Uwais is good-looking, charismatic, and deathly calm. His SWAT team raids the tower safe house of drug lord Tama (over the top evil Ray Sahetapy), lead by Lt. Jaka (earnest Joe Taslim). Tama commands from the top floor of the tower, and has his henchmen wreak havoc on those below. Rama has another more personal mission: He must rescue the soul of his prodigal brother Andi (strong and smart Donny Alamsyah). The story has been done before—reminiscent of Bruce Lee's "Game of Death". Once the automatic weapons play out, the movie goes wild—in a good way. The sword fighting is also amazing.I was not familiar with the Indonesian martial art Silat. Silat is like Muay Thai, close in elbows and knees. Silat also uses kung fu round kicks and blows. Uwais and Ruhian throw nice boxing hooks. There are also cool locks, chokes, and throws. Silat is beautiful and brutal.See "The Raid" for the electrifying martial arts action. The acting is solid and the story is derivative. The showcase fight scene with the brothers taking on Mad Dog is spectacular. I wonder how many times Evans had to film the scene. It was definitely worth it.

Review title: The Raid, a basic story but incredible action and mind blowing fight sequences
Review_body: The Raid is a fast paced, brutal and bloody action movie that is choreographed so well, insanely well. My point is that this film have a high level of enjoyment in it, each scene keeps you suspended and entertained. The Raid is about a elite squad that's tasked to infiltrate a high-rise building that's run by a ruthless drug lord, we follow Rama who is the rookie but really the best as he's capable with firearms and his deadliest weapon, martial arts. It's a very basic story but Gareth Evans succeeds in every way and made an amazing action movie, also great directing on his part!The handheld camera technique works well here, the crew and ensemble cast made the film work. It's one of my personal favorite action movies as it truly have everything an action film should have. The crew have really done a good job at making the action feel real if it's the guns or the hand to hand combat, each fight is suspenseful and powerful. The musical score helps with that aswell, making it flow well with the fights and choreography that the stunt coordinator did a magnificent job with.I wonder how they pulled off some things in this movie, like that fridge scene. There's also a fight sequence, a long one with Rama and Andi against Mad Dog. It's totally unrealistic but so good, like bloody great. Superb! I could watch that for hours because of the fight choreography that they had to learn.Iko Uwais is Rama. What a great martial artist and action star, just wow. This was the second time I watched The Raid and I'm still blown away by it, it was better the first time though but 80 minutes of the hundred were 10/10. I recommend it for action fans or martial arts movies.

Review title: One of the most astonish Indonesians martial arts action film!
Review_body: The Raid: Redemption (2011) is one the most astonish Indonesian martial arts action film I have ever seen. The most Action films I have seen were are Hong Kong action films with Bruce Lee, Jet Li and Jackie Chan. But this movie completely surprised me. The movie is delivered in perfect Die Hard-Jet Li's Meltdown (1995) style - (and the John Woo- Hard Boiled Style) -- you'll see lots of martial arts, gun plays, axes, knives and machetes. The stunts are completely insane in scale. The film is violent, and very gore bloody full action movie!!!! I haven't seen that kind of action martial arts film in any cinema. The most martial arts Hong Kong action films are from the 80's and barely 90's, but in 2011 there was this astonish Indonesian perfect martial arts action film. The violence the blood, the gory and action everything is perfect.The movie starts fast paced, entertaining with a plot story, you can go in to the story without hesitation and you are hooked up on the seat.A SWAT team takes it upon themselves to bring down a highly crime lord; the team enters a 30 floor apartment building in the middle of the ghetto where the crime lord is known to operate from. Once the SWAT team makes it to the fifth or sixth floor, the crime lord learns of their infiltration. The lights go out. The exits are blocked. Only then do we realize that the inhabitants of the apartment building are lethal gangsters, hit men, crazies and cop-killers. The crime lord speaks briefly into the building's intercom: kill these unwelcome visitors- be sure to have fun doing so- and be rewarded. Then all hell breaks loose! The fighting sequences are expertly choreographed and insanely realistic. You can actually feel the pain of the people getting their bones snapped like twigs. And the pacing and editing of the movie is simply phenomenal. Think of it as Tarantino bloody violent action film! An elite swat team has to fight their way through an apartment complex-turned-safe house full of Indonesia's most dangerous killers and gangsters in order to take down the notorious drug lord that runs it. From start to finish, I was on the edge of my seat, awestruck by the brutality and bloodshed that emanated from every scene. In the end, you're not going to walk away talking about how memorable the characters were or how well-developed the plot was. No, you're going to walk away feeling entirely breathless, almost as if you just got smacked upside the head with a shot of pure adrenaline. This is the kind of movie that doesn't pull any punches. It goes right for the gore and only gets more deliriously wild and intense from there. If you're a huge fan of action flicks like me, I urge you to watch "The Raid: Redemption". Yes, it's a foreign film with English subtitles, but believe me, it's well worth seeing. It's a slick, deranged, no-holds-barred astonish action seat movie, that'll knock your socks off and leave you speechless.This movie kicks ass! Iko Uwais as Rama police officer member of the SWAT team kicks ass and the fight scenes of no hold barred are astonish and very fast paced realistic.The only problem with the film I do have and why I gave it a 8 is because: there was a less shootout scenes, I was excepting more shout outs and used more automatic gun plays and hand guns. I was excepting the movie would be more mixed martial arts action film in a John Woo's---Style Hard Boiled, I was excepting more explosions not just one. Mostly I wanted that only one member of the SWAT team survives and not three, that would be perfect just like in Die Hard. I wish Rama would not had any help by fighting Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian) with his brother Andi (Donny Alamsyah) if those scenes would be cut the movie would have been much better and I would gave it a perfect 10. That Rama would have killed single handily drug lord leader Tama (Ray Sahetapy). I was also excepting that Tama would fight more with Rama not that he would be shot in the head by Wahyu (Pierre Gruno). At least that is my problem with the film that is why I prefer the sequel The Raid 2: Berandal (2014) over The Raid: Redemption (2011) because it had everything in it, that I was excepting in this film, it was in the next sequel film.The positive things about this film is that he saved Bowo (Tegar Satrya) and he arrested Wahyu (Pierre Gruno) and he did not killed them, he saved two people including his brother.Anyway this movie is what it is, a perfect 8, because it takes the vision of one of the most imaginative directors on Earth, and realizes them almost perfectly with all the tools that fit the task -- actors, stunts, puppetry and martial arts choreographer.The Raid: Redemption (Indonesian: Serbuan Maut, meaning The Deadly Raid; also known as just The Raid) is a 2011 Indonesian martial arts action film written and directed by Welsh filmmaker Gareth Evans and starring Iko Uwais.8/10 Grade: B+ Studio: PT.
