Merantau Films XYZ Films, Celluloid Nightmares, Sony Pictures Classics Stage 6 Films Starring: Iko Uwais, Joe Taslim, Donny Alamsyah, Yayan Ruhian, Pierre Gruno, Tegar Setrya, Ray Sahetapy Director: Gareth Evans Producer: Ario Sagantoro Writer: Gareth Evans Rated: R Running Time: 1 Hr. 41 Mins. Budget: $1.100.000 Box Office: $4.105.123

The Raid, a new non-stop cornucopia action film, comes from the most unlikely of sources – Indonesia. But don't let the country of origin fool you. The Raid is jam packed with some of the best action sequences we've seen in years and audiences are sure to walk away with an adrenaline rush punch to the gut that far exceeds their forked (over) entertainment dollar.Starring a bunch of actors we can guarantee you have never heard of and written and directed by Gareth Evans (another name you are surely not to recognize), The Raid offers big time action sequences chalked full of gunfights, knife fights and enough hand-to-hand combat to rival any movie in recent memory.The idea behind The Raid is remedial. A group of well armed police officers enter a 15-story apartment complex overflowing with a group of better armed drug dealers and bad guys intent on holding their ground. The police are lead by an over anxious Lieutenant who leads his squad of mostly rookies into the apartment complex where they are quickly over matched and out gunned. Their objective is to find the drug lord who resides on the 15th floor and bring him to justice. Easier said than done.Bodies on both sides of battle fall to the ground like rounds from a Gatling gun in an Arnold Schwarzenegger movie. The police – those that survived the opening shootout – are split into two groups with Jaka (Joe Taslim) fighting alongside the Lieutenant and a rookie officer, and Rama (Iko Uwais) who tries to protect an injured officer while battling the hordes of oncoming baddies.What ensues over the course of the next 80-minutes is a rip-roarin' blast of gratuitous bloodletting. The gun battles are more intense than the bank robbery scene in Michael Mann's Heat, the apartment hallway battles make the scene in Oldboy look like a Pixar film and the cops are as overmatched as U.S. Army Rangers were against an entire Somalian town Black Hawk Down.Director Gareth Evans clearly wants you to leave your brains at the door and celebrate in violent beatings and fight sequences that were stylishly choreographed and continue with such relentless regularity that you almost want to pause the projector to catch your breath before the next group of bare-fisted bruisers hit the screen. Our two main leads take more body blows than John McClane did in all four Die Hard films and their resilience and ability to be beaten to a pulp and yet have the ability and the strength to continue fighting is beyond this reviewer's comprehension.If there was but one small issue we had with the film it was that everyone who lived in the apartment complex had the fighting skills of an UFC righter or karate expert. Young, small, big or tall, they hall knew how to deliver a multiple high-kicks or at least take one and get right back up for more.There is a small twist in the film that is clearly evident a reel before the actual reveal on screen, but it hardly takes away from the fun filled excitement leading up to the plot turn.The sum of all its parts makes The Raid a must-see for anyone appreciative of non-stop battles where machetes are luxury and where a broken fluorescent tube can send a packed theatre into jubilant applause. It may lack the sophistication of The Departed, but it catered to an audience that couldn't get enough by the half-way mark and then was left gasping for air like a prized fighter in the 12th round towards its conclusion.www.killerreviews.com

Review title: Incredible action from an unlikely source
Review_body: Hong Kong and Japan have supplied us with some of the greatest action packed movies ever. The stunt work can be incredible and the whole artistry astounding, it's almost a ballet of violence. To my surprise, from a very unlikely source comes 'The Raid'. Filmed in Indonesia with full cast from there also (albeit directed by a Briton) this more than matches some of the best from the previously mentioned countries.A group of heavily armed police are sent into a tower block to bring down the well armed and prepared godfather. The gangs loyal to their master are more than a match and it's a battle to the death, with survival and escape as great importance as the original mission.The action is heavily violent and you will wince at points. The martial arts can be astounding to watch with great choreography. The lead characters also despite their star roles are never primadonnas either, which is refreshing.This is one strong movie. Excellent non-stop action with a good story. Everyone in the story was amazed by how it all flowed and even applauded the film at points throughout. It was that well made.Brilliant film and I'd highly recommend this to any action fans.

Gareth Evans said he wanted to make something closer to Assault on Precinct 13 than just another Martial Arts movie. As many young action directors inspired by John Carpenter's claustrophobic achievement, he fails to read the lesson till the end. Admittedly he only wanted to remember how the appropriate directing of half a dozen extras could appear like an army on screen.The Raid starts well with the sense that the building is the main character. As the SWAT team advances thru the first few floors, the movie is a tense thriller. Then the storyline forks, you no longer really care what floor you're on and fight scenes just happen along the way. The choreography is brilliant, the editing is great - save for the final fight which ridiculously last for minutes - but it's not the Assault thriller of the premise, it's only a Martial Arts tournament setting (Hello Bruce Lee).Another big flaw is to show the Big villain and his sidekicks. He is a nice actor but gets too much exposure whereas he should be melted with the building. His evil sense is as ludicrous as that of the Nicholson character in The Departed. And the sidekicks are not actors, they have zero charisma and are not made better by the dull dialogue.If you are expecting something more than a movie with nice fights, skip it.

I am not a massive fan of action films as I generally find them pretty tedious. This film however is so far over the top and so full of action that it really is hard not to be entertained by it. The plot is basic as cops try to storm the tower block home of a well known criminal though it does have a sub plot as to why they are there in the first place. This film is really just all about the action, fighting and bloodshed and that is your thing then you'll almost certainly like this. There are brilliantly executed fight scenes throughout especially the martial arts fights. Apparently The Raid had a pretty low budget so that makes the scenes even more impressive. If you are looking for a simple, easy to watch and entertaining film this is almost perfect.

Review title: "The Expendables" and "Ong Bak" in a blender!!!
Review_body: Here's The Lowedown on "The Raid: Redemption" (An Action/Martial Arts DVD review)...LOVED IT!! Become a fan of The Lowedown on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/The-Lowedown/386583633764 What's it about? In the Jakarta slums, a derelict apartment building has become a no-go area - even the police are unwilling to enter. It has become a safe-house for the most dangerous killers and gangsters. A SWAT team infiltrate the building, under the cover of darkness, to remove its owner - a notorious drug lord named Tama.What did I think? This was one of the best pure action movies I have seen in a long time. The fight scenes were so impressive (armed and unarmed), that it has you gripped from start to finish. If you take "Ong Bak" and "The Expendables" then put them in a blender...you get "The Raid: Redemption". Stick this one in your player ASAP.
Action on a different level. Everyone else is just catching up.

Sorry but I really didn't like this film at all. The plot centres around an A S.W.A.T. team who become trapped in a tenement run by a ruthless mobster and his army of killers and thugs. It could have been a good Martial Arts film but for my money there were way to many guns and the violence was totally over the top. Is it really necessary to show people's heads and limbs blown off just because you can? As for the Martial Arts, these were also a disappointment. Fight scenes way to long and drawn out and made unrealistic by the level of violence and injury that didn't seem to affect the main characters at all. As for that funny little guy who took on two others, sorry he wasn't in the least bit convincing. The main reason this didn't work though was the main character had zero personality. What made the early martial Arts films work, especially Bruce Lee and Jackie Chan was that the main character had personality and you found yourself routing for them. Quite frankly I lost interest in all the characters in this film after 5 minutes of them being on screen.

Review title: If you doesn't blow you away, it'll blow away the fridge!
Review_body: Don't get me wrong, I loved The Raid, but I thought that I'd be sitting here and giving it a raving 10/10 from the moment I saw the jaw-dropping trailer and read all of the really positive reviews which heavily praised its action. I read that the film was quite low on plot and character development and I thought that I'd be OK with that because it's a martial-arts film, but now I realise that I'm not entirely OK with that and I do need stronger narratives and characters in order to keep me interested. Thankfully, The Raid did actually have a narrative and good characters, as well as dialogue, but it's this that takes a back seat to put the action first, which is undoubtedly some of the greatest action sequences I've ever seen.The way some people were going on, it was as if The Raid was entirely action! The tagline is even '1 minute of romance, 99 minutes of action' (or something along the lines of that). But The Raid does actually have a story even if it's a simple one. I actually like a simple plot, because it means the film remains focused and you can get really involved in it and I did! I loved the evil owner, who had zero compassion which we saw from the minute we see him, shooting people in a line for reasons we don't know about. What The Raid lacked in its first 20 minutes or so is a hero! It wasn't clear who our protagonist was, and it's hard to feel attachments to 20-odd policeman who drop like flies (although it is fun to watch). Once our clear hero does emerge the film really hit its stride, and my worries were cleansed.Our hero is a very likable guy. He has more hair than John McClane and a less he-man attitude than John Rambo! Also, he's not called John! (But he probably will be in the remake) he's a really kick-ass man who knows his martial arts as well as Uma Thurman in Kill Bill. He is also not a total caricature as we see how his pregnant wife is on his mind, and we see a complex relationship with his brother. The Raid also features some surprising plot twists which I really liked! But mostly the story is all about survival. Our hero is basically left on his own, and he has to make his way up the building to the king-pin whilst shredding his way through some martial art-loving druggy minions. No, it's MORE entertaining than it sounds! Oh yes, the main show here in The Raid is the glorious action.Someone explained that The Expendables is the male equivalent of Sex in the City. He's wrong, The Raid is! Unless you know an action-loving girl then the majority of females are going to find this boring. My sister walked out after emerging from her sleep! The Raid also far surpasses The Expendables! What was wrong with The Expendables was what is wrong with the majority of action films today, and that is that the camera shakes around way too much, and the quick cuts are so quick that, with so many angles that it's impossible to tell what is going on. Well, The Raid puts a big fat stop to all of this. The action is shot and edited perfectly. There's a little shake but no turbulence, and there are very few edits so you know what's going on!I'd call The Raid more of a martial arts/kung fu film than an action film, as the guns fall out of play quite early on, leaving a lot of breath-taking fight scenes which may upset some old-school action fans e.g. My Mum, but I couldn't help but be in awe of the outstanding choreography. It felt almost like a dance film, with the lightening-fast, fluid movements being beautifully captured. My jaw dropped in some scenes, because they were just so intensely filmed that they made me feel out of breath! I really felt transported into the film and I felt every punch and kick, which is unusual is most action films. The Raid also isn't afraid about leaving little to the imagination wither, we see every gun shot, knife wound and back break. One of the most extraordinary sequences is when during a spectacular fight they jumped out a window, and the camera follows them as they fall out the window, still fighting! It's very cool.Michael Bay and other action directors could learn a lot from Welsh-man Gareth Evans (what's he doing in Indonesia?) It's some of the best action directing I've seen since Kill Bill. I could list a load of superlatives to describe its intensity, but you still need to just experience it for yourself. The Raid is one of the best action films I've seen. I'd even controversially say that it's better than Die Hard! The Raid might've not been as deep as I'd have liked it to have been, but hopefully the sequel can surpass that. The remake wouldn't be a patch on this, unless Gareth did it and a more accomplished writer came to the table. The Raid's action sequences blew me away! It's certainly a film I could watch again and again!

Review title: One of the Greatest, Most Well-Choreographed, Most Epic Action Movies of All Time
Review_body: The Raid: Redemption follows a S.W.A.T. team who enters a mob- controlled building in the hopes of taking down the crime boss at the top. Meanwhile, there seems to be something else happening that brought the team here in the first place. Holy moly, let's address the elephant in the room first, the action sequences. Wow. Just wow. The choreography is absolutely fantastic. Every fight is amazingly fluent, everything flows together perfectly, and it's just plain epic. Seriously, this some of the greatest action I've ever seen. If your going to see this movie for anything, you see it for how absolutely brutal, yet fantastically made, the action is. The story itself isn't heavily focused on, but it works. The way it's written makes it actually more realistic because not everything is just laid out for the audience and explained. The characters talk about the plot in a way where they aren't explaining everything to the audience, they're just talking like they both know everything about their conflict already. Unfortunately, the plot then ends up being a little unclear by the end, but at least the movie doesn't treat us like babies. Overall The Raid: Redemption is fantastic. The action is amazing and the story is well-written. As far as anything else goes, it's not great, but it doesn't need to be. It's not going for an amazing plot or anything, it's going for amazing action and by golly it delivers. It's an action movie through-and-through, and there's no real reason to judge it based on anything but that. In the end I would definitely recommend this movie.

Review title: Blood spurts, bones snap, skulls implode, furniture explodes
Review_body: At last, we have it: The first ten star film of the year. I was worried it might never happen. Then came The Raid.I'm not a fan of kung fu-type films and, whilst I admire Jackie Chan and appreciate he's incredibly skillful at what he does (i.e. not the acting!) his work leaves me cold. I'm not a fan of the protracted fights and the overriding feeling of watching a pantomime fight scene. And so I'd probably have ignored The Raid had it not been for an article I stumbled upon some months ago about a Welshman making an Indonesian film with a non-actor. The journalist thought, from the scenes he'd watched shooting, that it just might rock. Big time.It does. And more than that! I was quite literally stunned, jaw almost on the floor at times, and I will heartily recommend to all who care to listen. However, please note two points: 1. It is subtitled and, inexplicably, that appears to be a huge obstacle for some people (plebs! ☺) and 2. It is extremely violent. If those are issues, don't bother reading on and cross it off your list immediately.The Raid is a beautiful, nay, exquisite, bloody ballet. The choreography is mind-blowing in its intricacy and balance and the physical performances are mesmerizing. Blood spurts, bones snap, skulls implode, furniture explodes, gunfire hammers through walls, wood and flesh and the language, such as it is, has the deepest hue of blue. Be warned, it isn't an easy ride but the journey is a pleasure that must be repeated. A sequel is planned but why wait around when the original is begging to be watched again? The premise is simple: A decrepit tower block has become a haven for a crime lord, his violent minions, those who can ill-afford more desirable neighbourhoods and any number of petty thugs who chose safety within rather than without. A police chief launches a raid on the block with a team of raw(ish) recruits with the task of killing the kingpin and avoiding their own demise. Needless to say, all does not go according to plan. However, one of the cops, Rama (Iko Uwais) has no intention of dying and his own agenda to follow.The story goes that Welsh director Gareth Evans discovered martial arts champion Uwais while shooting a documentary in Indonesia and persuaded him to quit his job as a driver to star in a film written around his talent, namely The Raid. When you watch The Raid (there's no if about it, go and see it!) you'll understand why Evans went to such efforts. Understand before you go into the cinema that they shot in real time. There are no special effects to speed up the fighting. It's a blur because Uwais and his co-stars are that fast! It's almost a relief that it runs at only 101 minutes because I don't think my eyes could take much more.There are no complexities with the plot, dialogue is light and the subtitles do not in anyway hinder the viewing (for those plebs who ignored me and are still reading). It's a fast, loud, blistering assault on the senses where the music, whilst perfectly selected, plays second fiddle to the soundtrack of grunts, crashes and explosions. The foley artists earned their money on this one! I'm not going to wax lyrical about the editing, the cinematography, the casting, the physical effects, the set If I haven't persuaded you that The Raid is a 'must see' by now, nothing else I write will do so. And if I have, you'll find out for yourselves. One thing I will highlight is the end credit sequence. As a credits geek (it's a big no-no to talk through them or leave before they end and for me to do so is a protest at how awful a film is) they were a joy to read. There are no 'extras', no gimmicks or effects, just a list of character names and numbers the like of which I've never seen before.There are some who will condemn The Raid for it's content, subject matter and ability to delight with such extreme displays of armed and unarmed combat. If any of them are still reading, I'll leave you with a précis of a conversation I had as I left the cinema.As the lights went up, Marieke drew my attention to two ladies, two septuagenarian ladies, who had watched through to the bitter end. I raced after the couple to engage them in conversation and, as I reached them, they were nonchalantly discussing chopping up food in order to make it easier to swallow."Excuse me. I'm sorry to disturb you but, without wising to be rude, you're not the demographic one would expect to see in The Raid and I wondered, um, what are you doing here?" They smiled and took great pleasure in informing me, in broad Bristolian accents, that they'd read a glowing review in The Guardian and that The Watershed was screening it. "If The Watershed is showing it, it must be good. It's just much cheaper here." We discussed the film for perhaps ten minutes and it was clear that they saw beyond the violence and the language and saw the extreme beauty of the craftsmanship that went into every aspect of The Raid. For them it was the most challenging film they'd seen so far this year and one of the most rewarding.And if I didn't respect them enough for their opinions of the film and their enjoyment of TV delights The Killing, Borgen and Spiral, they certainly rocketed in my estimation with the last word I shall give them here: "We had a lot more fun tonight than we did last week in that awful film, what was it, oh yes, The Lucky One."Another film review from The Squiss.Like the Facebook page: http://on.fb.me/RpitOG

When I read that THE RAID was one of the best action films to come out in decades, I didn't believe it. I thought it was all a lot of hype. I'd heard that sort of thing before and ended up disappointed. But I can say honestly that this is NOT one of the best action films I've in decades. It is THE best, hands down.It's just extremely well done. There are so many amazing, tense sequences in here. I can't even begin to list them all. But the action is nonstop and feels very realistic. There is also some very good camerawork. The acting is good and the story is good, but it's really all about the action here. And even if you don't like subtitles, don't worry. There isn't all that much talking for most of the movie and you won't even notice it's subtitled after five minutes. Highly recommend.

Review title: Non stop action, but nothing more
Review_body: There is some great action here, but not much else. Go to a building, try to get to the top bad guy and leave again. Tons of fights, tons of killing, but nothing more. Some very good martial arts, but after all the raving I heard about this, I was a bit disappointed. Definitely watch with sub titles on because the English dub is horrible.

Review title: A celebration of martial arts and stunt work
Review_body: This is the epitome of a fun film. Leave your brain behind, sit back and watch the carnage unfold. There isn't too much more to 'The Raid' than that. It's a magnificent display of the art of stunt work and stunt performers, with some of the best hand to hand combat on screen I've seen.I usually dissect the plot of characters a little when reviewing a film, but with The Raid that's not really possible or necessary. Only one character gets any real 'development, which is rather flimsy and not particularly needed in all honesty. The plot is very simple, and exists purely to facilitate the outrageous and gritty action that runs through the film.The action is the selling point for this film, and it really is stellar. The initial gun focused action is quickly swapped for close quarters martial arts, producing some thoroughly violent encounters as you'd expect. The stunt team really do excel in this film, and the camera work does an excellent job of following the flailing fist and legs around the tight corridors of the apartment block, augmenting the sense of danger. My only criticism would be that by the final fight I was getting ever so slightly bored of the fighting. Overall I think the balance was good, but had the action continued for another fight or two I would have started to lose patience with it a tad.The Raid really is a marvellous display of martial arts and the craft of stunt work, and celebrates this work in triumphant fashion. It fails to garner a higher score simply because of the lack of plot or character development, but the action really is second to none and will most definitely entertain you for a couple of hours!

I have to say that this film was something else. Iko Uwais, (Rama) a S.W.A.T. member of twenty men who are brought in to take down a brutal mobster king pin Tama (Ray Sahetapy). Through their routine of infiltration a young boy they stumble upon was the catalyst to starting the most intense fighting using weapons or guns at their disposal. Now both Rama and his partners must find a way out before becoming the next casualty. Yet in the hideout with Tama, is a rogue wolf brother of Rama's who becomes the next one hunted. Through the entire building each squad member must face an opponent, in small or large groups. I must confess, that although I do not like Mui Tai boxing, it does show a great deal of intricate moves which one could become dizzy with. It reminds me of Tony Jaa in Ong Bak. Fantastic fight scenes, between the brothers and Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian). As for the story itself, it was slightly offbeat with the guess of who is in with the kingpin kind of thing. Most of the clues lead to their lieutenant who devised the raid in the first place. This told me it was the lieutenant in the first hour when Rama heard how no back up was coming to save them. However, moving around the building for the whole movie was a nice trick. You were never bored, action through out, but the characters needed to pick up a few more emotional sequences to make it more intense with the story. But -- to be fair, these days Indonesian films have become quite the trend now with new stories, new fights, and new ways to wow the crowd. Excellent acting from Iko Uwais. Much like Tony Jaa, they can fit any role.

Review title: Action does not get better than this
Review_body: A drug lord lives in a fortified apartment block. An elite squad of police infiltrate the building to arrest him. It does not go the way they wanted it to. That's the plot. There are a few more bells and whistles, including our main hero cop finding an unlikely ally in the building, but essentially this film is non-stop action. Extremely brutal and incredibly intricately staged incredible action. By distilling the crucial ingredients to their basic essence and working like hell to pull of some incredible fight choreography and insane stunt work, Gareth Evans has made the best action film of the last 20 years.

Review title: You may wind up with blood on your shirt....
Review_body: Tension. Tension. Shootout. Tension. Shootout. More Tension. Fight. Fight. Fight. Fight. This is The Raid in a nutshell. This film is a rock em' sock em' absolutely brutal beatdown of an action film that takes no prisoners, pulls no punches, and is not afraid of making you cringe. Plot be damned, because it's all about the video game-like action that sprinkles itself in the 90+ minutes of pure Indonesian mayhem.For those that still want to know what it's about, The Raid starts off with our male lead leaving his pregnant wife to do a mission. The mission is simple: raid a creepy abandoned building and arrest the guy responsible for running all the illegal nonsense. What follows are plot twists, plot turns, a few surprises, plenty of clichés, and enough action to cover two summer seasons. Not kidding in the least bit, action junkies will get their fix and some with this flick.The Raid's biggest strengths can be contributed to the direction and cinematography. This film lacks lighting; it lacks a polished look, and avoids the wide shot like the dickens--giving it a very gritty feel. Close-ups are abundant when building tension, when the stakes are raised, and especially when the fights are delivered. Containing some of the best-directed martial arts since Jackie Chan himself, the fights are extremely well-choreographed, tightly edited, and are so intense that during my viewing, half the audience walked out. This is no PG-13 fight flick, you'll see nasty body blow after blow, and see more knives than a butcher, and more fatalities than every Mortal Kombat game combined. The death and dismembered count is nice and high.For the nitpicky, the plot is definitely clichéd and definitely predictable. For the nitpicky, the acting is honestly not the best, and neither is the writing. But nobody is walking into this movie to focus on any type of story. You are entering this movie with three things in mind: action, carnage, and martial arts.And you will have plenty of all three.And perhaps way more than you can handle.

Now I saw this movie for one reason, and one reason only, it was hyped up beyond belief. I think the only two other movies that have come out this year that have been more hyped up are "The Hunger Games," and "The Cabin in the Woods." I really had no idea what this film was about going into it, I basically read a one sentence sympnosis of it. So, was the movie as good as everyone is making it out to be? Kinda.OK, I will say that for the most part, I really enjoyed this movie. The acting is great, I of course saw this with subtitles, so I got the actual actors and not someone dubbing over it. The fight scenes are very, very well choreographed. That's the main fun of the movie is the fighting and the violence. There is a lot of violence in this movie, and there are sometimes where it got hard to watch. I cringed several times. The villains are great, I just clenched my fists, waiting for them to die. And the plot was, really well done, I had a little trouble trying to keep up at times.But that is also one of the movies main problems, there were times where I just went "huh." That might not be a bad thing, but it hurt my enjoyment of the film. Also I wasn't a big fan of the characters, they aren't bad, but there are just too many of them and I really only gave a crap about two of them. And some characters do the stupidest things. There was a point when one of the villains has someone tied up. Aother good guy comes in, and he lets the other guy go so he can fight them both. And it's not like he has a weapon, he just decides to go 2 on 1.Other than that, I didn't have many problems with this film. It isn't too long, so it's worth seeing unless you aren't a fan of violent films.7.5/10

Brilliantly choreographed with some truly stunning fight scenes, both hand to hand martial arts and with the use of weapons. It is very brutal and there is plenty of gore so it's definitely not one for the squeamish. All the performances were excellent, I watched it in its native Indonesian with subtitles so I could better judge and I felt nobody missed a beat. I loved the music, it kept the pace of the film very well and added to the excitement of the fight scenes where needed. The time really flew (which is always a good sign) and, although there were a couple of quiet moments, it's pretty much full on all the way! I did like the plot as well; there were references to police corruption and also a nice little twist with one of the drug lord's men. Over all, it's one of the best martial arts films I've seen for quite a while! A definite 'must see' for any fan of the genre.SteelMonster's verdict: HIGHLY RECOMMENDEDMy score: 9.4/10.You can find an expanded version of this review on my blog: Thoughts of a SteelMonster.

Review title: A martial arts cinematic treat. Groundbreaking fight scenes.
Review_body: Quite honestly some of the best martial arts I've EVER seen. That could the be the entire review as it was pretty much the whole film. This film was low on story (what there was was predictable), but exceedingly high on action and graphic gore. In terms of action, this film was ground-breaking; the violence was up close and visceral - you saw knives going in, bullets blowing faces off and things going through people. I don't know how they did some of those SFX. I had no idea what this film was about, had no preconceptions, and thought it was a heist film, and didn't even know it had subtitles, thankfully the subtitles didn't subtract from the film as there wasn't much plot and most of the story was visual. I was pleasantly surprised but it's not what you would call a "pleasant" film, not uplifting or happy. However, it's amazing.Hats off and most honourable mention to Iko Uwais and Yayan Ruhian, the two actors, martial artists, stuntmen who carried this film... their fighting skill was mindblowing, original and unbelievably good. We had to rewind a few scenes as we just couldn't believe what we thought we'd just seen! I've never seen fight scenes like it. These two actors hopefully will become household names across the world not just in Indonesia... In a previous review I said that the film Warrior made Rambo and Predator look like a Disney film... this film made Warrior look like Finding Nemo. Well not quite, Warrior does have Tom Hardy! I would love to see a martial arts film with Ruhian, Uwais, Jackie Chan and Tiger Hu Chen as despite it being a very violent film, there was still some humour amongst the tense, nail-biting bits, but I missed the improvisation of Chan and the beautiful style and grace of Chen! Then by some miracle if you could get some Bruce and Brandon Lee... in there as well... you would have an EPIC. Whilst there was some bad language there wasn't anything in the film that was truly "bad" other than a high death toll, which doesn't really bother me, and the simple premise gave 100% focus to the fight scenes which were stunning.If you can bear the blood and gore, this is a cinematic treat.

The Raid: Redemption is the most awesome martial arts action film I have ever seen it's gory and bold and absolutely wonderful with tense parts moments when you just think this is the best ever made.In terms of the story though it's simple and has character development but the action recovers that fact that the story is a bit well simple. Iko Uwais who plays Rama is an amateur cop who has just started in the Jakarta SWAT team at first he sees his team mates being shot down but Rama gets very brave and shows his skill in the Indonesian Martial art Penciak Silat. In one scene there is ten minutes of pure awesomeness when Rama and his brother fight against one man Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian) in the end though the protagonist will always win. In the en though the mob leader gets shot in the head and that soon ends the awesome film that is The Raid. 10/10 gory and wonderful. Really want to watch the second one.

Review title: "Black Hawk Down" meets Asian Extreme Action
Review_body: Increasingly now, foreign filmmakers are making better Hollywood action movies than Hollywood is. In this case an English director who evidently now works in Indonesia seems to have mastered all the action story tenets despite this being only his 3rd feature film. Even more, the number of layers to this story parallels the number of floors in the apartment building that is at the centre of this film. All I could think of is how Hollywood will eventually commandeer this film and make a lifeless by-the-numbers knock-off that will only stain the original. And of course, the budget of the original is about the same as a Hollywood B-list movie actor's salary.This film is a disciple of the Asian extreme action genre, with over-the-top karate and acrobatics mixed with guns and violence. Betrayal isn't just a plot twist in these films, it's the first act. At least 5 or 6 betrayals are expected in these type of films where thieves betray other thieves, cops betray other cops, and honest guys get betrayed by best friends. What makes this film a standout is the unflinching action and well choreographed fight sequences by leads Yayan Ruhian and Iko Uwais. Early Jackie Chan movies got this kind of notice overseas because of their energy and gifted action instincts. Here, Gareth Evans is a one man powerhouse writer, director, and editor, masterminding this intricate chess match of good guys trapped on the sixth floor, with angry thugs coming up from the fifth floor and determined killers descending from the seventh floor. You feel our heroes feel trapped and vulnerable. Evans finds sources of tension from many places. The apartment building has tenants with unknown loyalties. The man heading the raid has unknown motives. Each character is well established with a minimum amount of screen time, keeping the action going.I was urged by a movie reviewer to see this film, describing it as one of the best action movies ever made. And you have to agree, this film, after providing a few minutes of backstory, takes off straight into the police raid of the apartment building filled with bad guys and a gang lord. Cinematography takes lessons from "Saving Private Ryan", using hand-held documentary style footage during firefights, and blasting the soundtrack with dozens of loud guns firing at once. The pulsing synthesiser score also hits with the punchy music stabs that propel the momentum as the police troops make their way up to the big bad guy on the top floor.Action sequences are creative and provide new angles and fight tactics that keep the hand-to-hand combat kinetic. Fans of the Bourne movies are encouraged to seek this out. (Not a coincidence that a Bourne Legacy trailer played before this showing). Many human moments also ground this film. An innocent man caught in the crossfire, gets asked to risk his life. A police squad leader who gets frustrated when the man conducting the raid puts his troops at risk. A child hired as lookout for the gang lord must die in order to prevent him from sounding the alarm.There is an intensity to this film that resembles scenes from "Black Hawk Down", with very intelligent setups for conflict, and innovative approaches to getting from point A to point B. This fresh drive, propelled by good guy Iko Uwais makes this 1 hour 40 minute film zip along with no time out to catch your breath. The fact this film is subtitled will prevent it from being a widespread hit, although it will no doubt have a long life on DVD. Instead, I expect director Gareth Evans to be directing movies with 150 times the budget of this small gem within a very short time.

It baffles me that a subtitle "Redemption" must be added to the name of the movie, which is already perfect as it is - "The Raid". Adding the subtitle to the movie merely adds nothing more but confusion, as the audience will be looking for a character looking for that trait. Roger Ebert in his review gave the movie 1 out of 4 stars and expressed his bewilderment over this issue. As if the subtitle will make the movie sound cooler than it already is.No matter. "The Raid" is quite essentially one of the most brutal and violent, and most relentless since John Woo's "Hard-Boiled", action thriller ever made. Think the 30-minute shootout in "Hard-Boiled" and fight sequences in "Ong-Bak" and "Tom-Yum Goong" combined and stretched into 90 minutes and you get "The Raid". It is a gung-ho exercise in style and choreography. To criticize the plot is in futility. It's killed or be killed. Simple but effective, like it's lead character Rama, the film aims straight for the jugular.Responsible for this rush are rapidly-rising Indonesian martial-arts star Iko Uwais and Welsh director Gareth Evans, the same team who brought us the impressive "Merantau" years ago. Like "Merantau", "The Raid" is chock-laden of adrenaline pumping action sequences and elaborately-choreographed Silat-infused fight sequences. Unlike the former, however, "The Raid" unleashes Silat at its brutal bone-breaking, head-busting, neck-snapping, gut-slashing, knife-stabbing, kneecap- crushing best. Uwais clearly establishes himself as a now-dominant force in the martial-arts movie industry, and can proudly rank himself up there with fellow modern martial-arts pain mongers Donnie Yen and Tony Jaa (whom he resembles apparently). He also manages to give out some acting chops, unlike most martial-arts stars today. Evans is also on the same path in terms of action-filmmaking, his frenetic and kinetic direction really rivets the film into a visceral viewing experience.Thanks to some gritty cinematography and production design, "The Raid" immerses the audience into the situation at hand, although (sadly I have watched the American release) the music score does not somehow do the job in some scenes. The ending, I feel, is a bit of a cop-out. Too often modern action movies end this way, and I really hoped it would be like how the 80's-90's action films ended - with a bang instead of a puff.Does the film glorify violence? There is certainly non-stop brutal and sadistic bloody violence that it could be called a game-changer for action films. I would have to say that - yes, the film does indeed glorify violence, but in that 80s-90s way in which the clearly- established-as-evil bad guys are mowed down relentlessly by the good guys as the audience cheers in support of the heroes. The same thing happened here. The audience I went with was small, but they were all whooping whenever a goon gets dispatched with style."The Raid" could be a hit, if the marketing would improve. Is it one of the best action movies ever made - a game changer? Not really. But it is definitely one of the most brutal and relentless of recent times. Let's hope Hollywood doesn't come-a-calling so soon...Overall rating: 69/100

Review title: First class action movie with a raw intensity I've only seen in horror movies
Review_body: I had heard about THE RAID before it came out but I was unable to find out when it would come out so I struggled to find it. What I didn't know was that the film was Indonesian. But that didn't worry me since I'm partial to foreign films. So I eventually found this film on Blu-Ray (The DVD was sold out.) and saw it and everybody did say this was the best action movie in a long time and its the first time a film with a lot of hype surpassed my expectations by far.This film was fast. intense and almost never lets up. in between the action scenes were the only moments I could catch my breath. The action was just unbelievable. Although I know a few people personally that will definitely complain about it because of the violence but to be honest those people are morons.All in All, its a first class action movie with a raw intensity that I've only ever seen in horror movies THE HILLS HAVE EYES remake and REC and no matter how much people praise it it will still blow you away. Literally.

"The Raid: Redemption" is unwatchably bad – a film that has no ambition other than to be noisy, aggressive, and relentlessly violent. Watching it is a little like being trapped in an arcade game and having absolutely no control over it. The characters, developed solely on shallow and overused clichés, are essentially targets in a shooting gallery, most of them serving no purpose apart from awaiting their cue to die in a savage attack. There are basically three types of weapons featured in this film: (1) Guns; (2) machetes; (3) human fists. The first two are used in scenes so brainless and bloody that they transcend goofy entertainment and achieve shameless exploitation status. The third, as you may have surmised, puts the film in the category of martial arts, a genre that has nothing to offer apart from pointless spectacle.Most of the action is captured on the Queasy Cam, so even if you do appreciate martial arts, the picture is usually so shaky that the choreography is virtually undetectable. The only time the camera holds still is when someone is stabbed, or shot, or sliced, or having their backs broken or throats slit. Writer/director Gareth Evans doesn't care about a genuine adrenaline rush, nor apparently about humanizing his characters. I'm not against cinematic violence, but it can't simply be glorified. It has to have some meaning, some sense that it belongs in the story. The only way such a thing is possible is if you take the time to develop your characters into people we can actually care about. Otherwise, we have little more than pieces of meat in a grocery store – neatly saran-wrapped but giving no indication that they were once a part of something living.The film does occasionally pause to take its breath, but that doesn't mean it delves into anything resembling a plot. Not by my understanding, at least. The few scraps of information I gathered were not only maddeningly conventional but also so poorly developed that it was next to impossible to determine who was doing what and why. Even if there is a plot, it's unlikely that any potential audience will hold the slightest interest in it. All we're made to focus on is the violence, perhaps in the misguided belief that what was being depicted was escapist fun. A masked superhero getting into hand-to-hand combat with his archenemy is escapist fun; men getting their brains blown out against filthy concrete walls, on the other hand, is unpleasant and needlessly excessive.The set up, so far as I can tell, involves a gang of madmen and murderers housed up in a derelict apartment building. No rival gang is able to penetrate its walls. Neither are the police. That's because it's overseen by a ruthless crime lord named Tama Riyadi (Ray Sahetapy), who has so many surveillance cameras hidden all throughout the building that it isn't possible to get anything past him. Sent in to take the crime lord down is a surprisingly small squad of a SWAT raid team led by Lieutenant Wahyu (Pierre Gruno), a senior police officer. Many recognize this mission as a fool's errand, and so it is, although decency prevents me from telling you why. The main character is a member of this rookie team. His name is Rama (Iko Uwais), and at the start of the film, he leaves behind a pregnant wife.Rama has reasons for taking part in this mission apart from the obvious. I will not say what they are, as I'm not allowed to spoil anything for you. What I will say is that it factors into a plot twist so manufactured that it might as well listed in a rulebook of clichés. Rama and his team navigate the floors of the building one by one, repeatedly running into ambushes of men with machine guns and machetes. I'll spare you graphic descriptions of the many bullet wounds and hack jobs shown all throughout, although I feel it necessary to warn you that one of the people killed is a boy no older than twelve. As the rookie team is decimated one by one, Rama will take part in a completely unnecessary and unresolved subplot involving a frightened tenant and his ill wife, who needs her medication.As of the date this review was written, "The Raid: Redemption" has earned an 83% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes. Am I the only one baffled by this? Exactly what is it about senseless carnage that audiences and critics find so appealing? This is an appalling movie that mistakes brutality and bloodshed for entertaining action violence. That most of this shot with cameras that appear to be caught in an earthquake doesn't help matters much, nor does the fact that the color scheme is dim and muddy. Even the blood, which basically replaces paint for the walls and floors, is an ugly dark shade, looking more like the contents of a sewer pipe than like an organic fluid. If a movie like this qualifies as praiseworthy, a serious shift in thought will soon be our only salvation.-- Chris Pandolfi (www.atatheaternearyou.net)

Review title: Not your average martial-art themed action flick, but every other can become a child's play after seeing this.
Review_body: Martial arts has always been a fascination to the world at least in the movies since Bruce Lee's foray into Hollywood. The same enthusiasm has been carried forward by Jackie Chan, Jet Li, Tony Jaa and the likes in their own style while adapting to changing times. Thus far, the primary combination has always been that of martial arts, modern technology and modern crime world along with a healthy dose of PG entertainment thrown in with occasional fantasy setups and animation. With 'The Raid: Redemption', it is taken to a whole new territory of gore, grit and overall graphic violence which marks a definitive shift in its target audience while putting the Indonesian movie industry in the global map of cinema along the way.Rama (Iko Uwais) is a rookie in the tactical police team which has been assigned to engage a crime syndicate operating from an apartment building. The team is led by Jaka (Joe Taslim) based on the intel procured from Wahyu (Pierre Gruno) and the operation was expected to be quick and silent. The mob boss Tama (Ray Sahetapy), his muscle Mad Dog (Yayan Ruhian) and brain Andi (Donny Alamsyah) along with a huge network of spotters (generally children), surveillance cameras and mercenaries was underestimated by the tactical team. The whole operation goes downhill as soon as it starts with body count rising and a never ending barrage of bad guys popping up in every corner. Rama and Wahyu have their own agenda amid all the chaos. Can they make it out alive?You get a similar scenario as that of 'Black Hawk Down' where a large and sophisticated military team go into Somalia for a quick and clean mission but end up losing many men and the rest scared and desperate to get back in one piece. 'The Raid' isn't about getting back in one piece but to pursue on relentlessly and at the same time playing for the masses every opportunity it gets. The graphic violence and the gore is on another level compared to movies of this genre. Even though there are a lot of gun battles, there are even more fist and knife fights which is where things get murkier. Skulls crushed, arms and legs broken, spines twisted, jaws cracked, torsos slashed and blood everywhere. Definitely not your average action movie. Considering the entire story is just the movie's namesake - a raid, even though the twists, revelations, human relationships etc. are all projected with the right intensity and strategically timed - it is the visual display of those martial arts combined with graphic violence that wins big for it. The action choreography is very innovative where the kicks and punches come in lightening pace and bodies are crushed in ways a normal viewer wouldn't have imagined. Complementing it is the excellent cinematography where each kick and punch is captured and projected with the maximum intensity for genre audience's pleasure. Generally the acting in Asian movies are a little overboard, but 'The Raid' makes sure the standard is very different from normal by maintaining the correct tone and the actors are to be commended for it. With a short runtime, crisp screenplay and enough twists in the script to keep the viewer engaged, the movie is a complete package for whoever can stomach the gore and violence.Not your average martial-art themed action flick, but every other can become a child's play after seeing this.

The story is simple: Iku Uwais has his wife pregnant and has to say goodbye for an operative. He must intervene a building that is full of thugs. Uwais is the only one who knows his brother is there, and has the secret idea of rescuing him. The operatives are linked to corrupt intrigue that will leave them very unwell. The villain of the story is a paranoid who is surrounded by a skilled fighter, Iku's brother and a group of tenants where almost no one is innocent but who in the average are very dangerous. Once the action begins there will be no rest for the viewer; you can feel the tiredness of the protagonists after each fight. Director Gareth Evans is a Welsh man who found fame and fortune in Indonesia, directing two of the greatest action films of all time. He's the new John Woo, and I take my hat off with him. With a little budget you can achieve a masterpiece that leaves a decadent Hollywood reddened with envy. Extraordinary, magical and exhausting, it is a film that has no defect. A masterpiece.

Pros:
1. The score lathers the film with an incessant heart-pumping and adrenaline-fuelled atmosphere.
2. The colour palette adds an oppressive and gritty feel to the movie.
3. There is a masterful build-up of tension and suspense.
4. The gore is brutal and impactful. The film also knows when to reign in the gore to make sure it doesn't become repetitive.
5. The action/ fight scenes are beautifully choreographed, enthralling to watch, and extremely fluid in their execution.
6. The cinematography, for the most part, is great and displays some really unique and experimental shots.
7. Both Iko Uwais (Rama) and Yayan Ruhian (Mad Dog) give fantastic physical performances.
8. The movie is very well-paced. It's quick which gives the film an appropriately high-octane feel, but it's not too fast so you can still be invested in the characters and the goings-on.Cons:
1. There is some obnoxious overuse of shaky-cam which also ends up obscuring some of the action.

Review title: I must be the only person not over the moon about this movie.
Review_body: Not every movie needs a heart to be entertaining. Sometimes, movies don't even need a brain either. The Raid: Redemption is one such film that tries to test this out, unfortunately, it's doing so in all the wrong ways. One word flashed through my mind when this movie finished: OVERRATED! The thing that struck me about this movie is how Kill Bill it feels. The movie reminded me of something Quentin Tarantino might have made, only more indulgent in violence, and conversations meant to build tension aren't showcased nearly as much. However, what Tarantino would have excelled at, this movie flails and fails at. Characteristically flat and inconsistently paced, the whole thing gets very tiring, very quickly. The performances come across as flat, and any genuine thrills from the action sequences are short lived, especially in the movie's final battle, which just goes on and on and on... Between the overcooked action and the dull breaks in between, the tonal shifts become a headache.Saving graces still find their way through. The action scenes feature some slick - if superfluous - choreography, and some pretty creative violence now that I think about it, and the music by Mike Shinoda and Joe Trapanese is really good (FINALLY! An electronic score that actually WORKS!), but that's as close to complimentary as I'm willing to go. I know the movie was supposed to be over the top, but you have to draw the line somewhere. This was just overkill.**/ *****

Review title: Rarely has the Big Dumb Action Movie Been Bigger, Dumber or More Fun Than This
Review_body: The Raid: Redemption is the most violent, ridiculously over the top action movie I have ever seen. It could be titled Violence: The Movie with complete accuracy. I don't think I've ever seen so many punches, kicks, and bullets before. And I know I've never seen so many furniture based attacks or men swung around by their legs. This is the kind of film that dares to ask if you can make a movie entirely out of shootouts, explosions, and martial arts, and it answers that question with a resounding yes. You can make that movie, and it will be awesome.Let me start with a little background. I first heard of this movie in a Robert Brockway column entitled "The Most Baffling Subtitles in Foreign Action Movie History" which detailed his experiences watching a poorly translated bootleg of the film. Reading his article, I knew that this movie was the kind of thing I had to see, even without lines like "You must be rest because of both" and "After you see it I sat in s****y pants." I mean where else can you see a guy doing Kung Fu with a florescent tube sticking out of his neck?The brief excuse for a plot involves an elite squad of police launching a raid on a rundown high rise run by one of Jakarta's most notorious crime lords. As they approach the building we get an expository speech about the villain and his chief henchmen, who are made to sound powerful and dangerous beyond all belief. Then we see them; three guys in T-shirts, the leader eating a bowl of ramen. It would seem that his reputation is undeserved. Next we see him finish eating and casually execute half a dozen men, and that impression is immediately dispelled. Then the cops enter the building, and from there it's nonstop action and brutal violence.And I mean brutal. People are stabbed, shot, garroted, strangled, thrown through windows, crushed under filing cabinets and more. At one point a man is hoisted into the air by an axe embedded in his shoulder, slammed to the ground, then axed again. I lost track of the body count less than a minute after the first shot was fired. And there are many, many shots fired. Nor does the Raid stick to that old trope where hundreds of bullets are fired but the heroes don't get hit. Lots of heroes get hit, and most of them die. And the exploding fridge gambit was one of the most original maneuvers used in an action film. John McLane would be proud.If the shootouts and explosions are excellent, the fight scenes are unbelievable. Beyond the standard punch and kick, you have men somersaulting out of arm locks, swinging enemies across the room by their ankles, and delivering spinning kicks to the back of heads. Heroes easily hold off three or more adversaries at a time, turning their attacks against them and impaling them on their allies weapons. This movie doesn't have time for the one at a time attack rule. The blows and parries come incredibly fast, and are only made more impressive by the fact that the moves are real. The low effects budget left no money for wire-fighting techniques, so the actors trained with Indonesian Special Forces instead.If you are at all squeamish or under seventeen, stay away. If you are looking for highbrow fare with any kind of message or moral, keep looking. But if you want nonstop heart pounding action, this is your movie. I can hardly wait for the announced sequel, or the English language remake.
An Indonesian action film that stays entertaining throughout. No filler or boring scenes. I suggest you watch it.

Review title: It is just a martial arts movie
Review_body: I saw the move as I understood that it was an action movie, thriller and had an interesting story line.It is an action movie - only.A swat team get 'trapped' inside a building on the thinnest of pretense.Ever since Alien people have been dreaming up ways of getting people confined in small dark places. This one couldn't find a plausible reason, but went ahead anyway.The basic story is then just a background for an endless stream of fight sequences.If you are in to martial arts and like the sound of lots of Asian men squealing then this is for you.But I went to see an intelligent movie with twists and suspense. It was a knock-out blow for my hopes.

I love Asian movies, and especially when it contains new actors. This movie is about a group of cops entering a big building filled with big criminals, to kill then all. The reason I rate this movie low, is because this movie could have been less longer, if the cops would have had a bazooka and leave the whole building to explode. In that way there would have been less victims among the cops.The action, fighting scenes, were awesome! Yayan Ruhian was gruesome. This fight he had against the two brothers in the small room was terrific. This guy went on and on, he was just a beast. I liked the fact that not only the cops could fight well, but the bad guys also. Almost every guy had his own fighting skills and techniques. The story was a bit lame. At the end some of the cops leave the building. I did not understand why they didn't get shot by the neighbors. This cop who had the leading role threw an other guy and himself outside the building through a window and when he got back inside he stayed a long time beside the window. Why didn't he get shot in the head? So, great movie but not flawless.

A S.W.A.T team, a building that only houses murders, drug dealers and criminals from the worst and a mission: to reach the top floor and arrest the owner of the building.The Raid is probably one of the most true to the name and genre (action and martial arts) films ever made. The plor is linear, has a goal from the start and everything unfolds around reaching that goal, in a very competent way, and with nothing to "undermine" the viewer's attention.The fight scenes (hand-to-hand and weapons) are probably the best rver rehearsed and filmed in cinema, and from the point of view that we see them, it is as if we were in the same room as those characters, which makes the experience tense and claustrophobic.It's very graphic, with violence, blood and intensity from the first to the hundredth minute, and one can only be thankful for that.Highly recommended.

A really cracking action movie. Excellent martial arts, good plot, great choreography, decent characters, original. Blew me away when I first saw it and watched it for about the 4th time yesterday and still loved it.

After seeing The Raid 2 I had to see the original and it was great. Seriously, it is because of movies like this that one can feel confident that martial arts movies are progressing in the right direction.The story unfolds at a nice even rate keeping the viewer waiting for the finale where we will understand exactly how far the characters will go for whatever reason they give us. The truth is though we don't care so long as there's plenty of lethal violence and blood shedding.The Raid Redemption is a very cohesively constructed and portrayed story full of action and adventure, an absolute joy to watch. A must see for any martial arts movie fan. It's basically martial arts porn and beautiful porn at that.

Alright, the action isn't quite non-stop, but it is pretty close. That being said they have actually managed to get a bit of a story thrown in, a relatively solid story at that.The premise is that a SWAT team, mostly full of rookies, is sent in to an apartment building to extract a crime lord. They have to deal with the fact that most of the tenants of the building are criminals, there are lookouts on every floor and a video surveillance system. It also becomes clear rather quickly that the lieutenant leading the assault isn't on the up and up.The first portion of the movie starts with the SWAT team doing what they do best. Methodically and quietly clearing the building as they move ever upward. Then things fall apart and they are in an extended gun battle.The action in the movie isn't limited to gun fights. There is a scene that reminded me of the hallway scene in Old Boy, but with knives, tonfa (police baton) and one cop marching through dozens of bad guys. There is also time for a couple of brutal hand-to-hand fights.The plot I alluded to earlier is hard to outline without spoiling the movie. It is clear that ulterior motives abound, most obviously in the lieutenant who arranges the raid. But as the movie unfolds, it becomes clear that there is more going on. I'm not saying the plot would win any Oscars, but I was pleasantly surprised at how well it played out.

Review title: High Flying Martial Arts Makes an Impression
Review_body: You want action? You got it. Explosive gun fighting for the first third of the movie, then electric hand to hand combat takes over. No shortage of high energy action. These guys fight for ten minutes straight and are barely breathing through their mouth by the end of it, clearly they had their coffee that morning.There's not too much plot wise. The police force, specifically the higher ups are obviously in many ways corrupt, and the featured SWAT team are essentially lambs to the slaughter... Enter Rama (Iko Uwais). Iko and other cast members get to show off their mad Martial Arts skills, which sets this apart from many other standard action flicks. Most likely the Hollywood introduction of the Indonesian Martial Art 'Pencak Silat', which has become prevalent in modern action movies such as the 'John Wick' series, and most recently 'Extraction'.I found it somewhat amusing that when the SWAT team either lost their guns or ran out of ammo, conveniently the bad guys did too. From thereon they all resorted to only machetes or hand to hand. And man, these guys can take incredible non stop beatings, and still look pretty good afterwards.In any case, quality effects and stunts make this very entertaining for any action junkie.

Review title: An Awesome and Amazing Martial Arts Film with Powerful and Brutal Action
Review_body: I have loads of Martial Films by Martial Art Film Actors such as Bruce Lee, Jet Li, Jackie Chan, Tony Jaa, John Liu, Michael Jai White, Scott Adkins, Donnie Yen, Johnny Nguyen, Sasha Mitchell, Steven Seagal, Steve Austin etc and all of their films are absolutely brilliant. I don't like to rate them differently in scores and I think they all deserve 10/10. The Raid starring Iko Uwais and Yayan Ruhian is an absolutely brilliant Martial Arts Thriller with lots of tense, brutal and powerful Martial Arts fights and the acting by Iko Uwais as Rama and Yayan Ruhian as Mad Dog is brilliant. These two actors are two very strong men and show their power in the film against each other and against others in the film. I have The Raid and The Raid 2 on DVD and I just loved watching The Raid because even though it was pretty violent, it also was a very enjoyable film to watch.

Not many movies pump you and you feel energetic after a some point of elapsed time in the movie. You have to swipe a building filled with drug-lords and criminals and once you are inside, there's no way outside and the only way left is to do or die.I remember the same concept movie was Dredd but this one stole the show through it's flawless action techniques. Iko Uwais did perfect job by his fighting skills and so did Gareth Evans in direction. I also found the background music which followed with kicks and punches and was equally gripping.Good Indonesian experiment film and anytime action watch.

Review title: The Raid: Redemption – The new benchmark in martial art entertainment. Beautiful too.
Review_body: Watching big budget movies is predictable at times- the mass media marketing campaigns, interviews, trailers, sort of take away all the suspense, reveals plots and sets expectations. Watching relatively unknown movies on the other hand can often be a serendipitous journey- you never know when you might unearth a hidden gem. And when you do so, no force in the world should stop you from spreading the word, so here is my homage to the best action movie in decades- The Raid: Redemption.The Raid: Redemption is an Indonesian film whose USP is a nonstop goulash of brilliantly choreographed fights, the language of which is the hitherto unknown Silat. Silat refers to an ancient marital art originating from the Indonesian and Malaysian archipelago, and while on the face of it looks similar to the popular Muay Thai (Thai kick-boxing)- it differs from the latter through its ability to be unconventional- using a variety of moves including strikes, joint manipulation, throws, bladed weaponry, cheat strikes or some combination thereof, unlike Muay Thai which is a never ending hand to hand full contact strike-fest. Cutting to the plot- there is thankfully precious little, and it is a simple cops vs robbers story. The film is set somewhere in Indonesia and has a video game-like feel about it- on the right corner, are 20 elite cops, while on the left corner sits one ruthless gang-lord, and between the right and corner stands 200 henchmen, and 30 floors of hell. No need for character development or background stories- crime lord Tama based out of a dilapidated building needs to be taken down, and the cops set out to do so with righteous earnest. Unfortunately, as they find out- they are hopelessly out-gunned, out-thought and outnumbered, as it is in the best interests of residents of the building to protect their crime lord, and they do so with gusto, with guns, with machetes, with pretty much anything they can lay hands on. In a matter of minutes, most of the cops are butchered, leaving a tattered few to complete the mission. The language of the movie, and i cant stress this more, is not Indonesian, but Silat. Everyone seems to have had attained proficiency in Silat in this movie- so battle after battle, there are punches, kicks, snapped necks, broken bones, crushed skulls, dismembered body parts, exploding heads and more- all that a hardcore action fan could wish for. To the credit of director Gareth Evans is that he makes all that look poetic as well as brutal at the same time. Of special mention is the editing which makes it all seamless- no shaky camera, slow motion shots here, just pure, unadulterated, close quarter action. The camera moves all along and through the floors, and bursting walls, to capture unexplored angles and visceral, heart pounding action. Which also showcases the physical prowess of the little known actors, who unlike their flashy Western counterparts, throw no punch lines after kills, they just go about it with utmost seriousness. Speaking of actors- the hero- Iko Uwais can send Tony Jaa crying home to mommy- he has the face of a kid, but give him a villain or dozen, and he transforms into a killing machine with devastating moves, and impeccable efficiency- and to top it, he does rather deliver his few lines rather well too. The final confrontation between him and chief henchman "Mad Dog"- is perhaps the most intensely choreographed fight i have ever seen- they set upon each other, pardon the pun, like rabid mad dogs, and they don't know when to stop- one of them keeps slugging even with a tube-light through his throat.Bottomline, The Raid: Redemption is a path breaking movie, because it does make you forget all other action movies. It knows its audience and exceeds their expectations- pacing, energy, beauty, blood. It does enough to revive interest in an endangered genre- that of unapologetic, high testosterone action, in addition to delivering a kick that will keep drifting you to its world for days. It seems there will be a sequel as well as a big budget Hollywood remake. But part of the appeal of the movie is its raw presentation, which the Hollywood remake is sure to miss out. I am among those few who see beauty in violence, and by that account, The Raid: Redemption is one of the most beautiful movies I have ever seen. 10/10 for hardcore martial arts action buffs- Available in DVD right about now.
An Indonesian action movie. A raid into an impenetrable block of sleezy tenements. Full of blood, gore and action packed violence. Very little dialogue. And plot. But it works as an action movie.

Review title: This is action. This is it.
Review_body: I'm one of those prejudiced individuals who rarely watch non-English speaking films. Sometimes I don't like a certain language (especially Swedish or french movies), sometimes I can't tell people apart from each other (especially Asian movies). I know I'm an idiot, but that's why it took me some time before I watched this one. I'm so glad I did. Just watched it on blu-ray. My blu-ray had no features or extras, so that was disappointing. The movie however was far from it.There is so much to like about this film. I'll try to explain why I enjoyed this:1) The environment. A confined building with many floors. It makes that much difference to me when the environment is not only realistic, but cramped in a manner that makes the action exciting and creative, adding to the overall intensity.2) The brutality and choreography in the fights. There's some quite imaginative stuff here, and lots of it - there is no way anyone can say that there is not enough action in "The raid redemption". Trust me, there is. This is not your usual PG13-pudding. There is an abundance of shooting, stabbing, punching, breaking bones and everything you can think of. Everything is shown in a brutal manner, and what I like the most about it is that the movie pushes forward with such a pace that it doesn't really overdramatize or dwell on the gore, it all just happens in the heat of everything. This makes the violence both satisfying and not too hard on the viewer.3) This is an action movie and nothing else. No complicated story lines, no romance, not much character development but straight to the point instead. The movie gives enough reasons for what is happening, and it's easy to enjoy it as it is: "just" an action movie with nothing in it to distract you from what's it all about. In many ways it feels much less silly than most action films: since it's not trying to build up much of a story, it doesn't fail on the terms of story. Same with characters. 4) This is how you use a budget. A little over one million dollars? Simply amazing. "Green Lantern" cost 200+ million dollars and it was a mess without any passion in it. Granted, not the best example, but you get the point. When you love what you do and you're good at it - while surrounded with a good crew - you get this. Many shots are genuinely very well made and impressive. Even a 5-second continuous shot with a moving camera can look pretty amazing when you see how cramped and lightning fast the action can be with multiple people fighting each other. It's all quality.I liked the actors. Plenty of good stuff (read: fighting and/or looking cool or evil) from Iko Uwais, Joe Taslim and Yayan Ruhian to name a few. Everyone did their job.This is a very similar film to "Dredd". In fact, many would say that "Dredd" blatantly ripped off "The raid redemption" with the concept of making a multi-story building as the setting. Maybe it did to an extent, but "Dredd" is still a good film while "The raid redemption" is naturally more original. If I'd have to compare the two, I'd say that this one has definitely more action and the emphasis is on martial arts instead of guns and the surrounding fantasy world.What I didn't like? I didn't always like the soundtrack. Sometimes it sounded too...generic and lazy. Perhaps there was a little too much action at times, if that can be considered a flaw in a movie like this. That's it. No other complaints.If you like brutal, intense action and/or martial arts to boot, check this one out. You might enjoy it as much as I did.

Review title: Non-stop, edge of your seat action: The Raid is THE definitive action film
Review_body: 2 hours of non-stop, jaw-dropping action. The choreography of Serbuan maut (2011) is a sight to be seen; how they made this film will always elude me. Simply put, this is the definitive action film and maybe the best martial arts film ever. Awesome!

The Raid: Redemption is an Indonesian martial arts action film, and a great one at that. This movie is already considered by many to be one of the best action movies of the decade and it shows why. The Raid is essentially a video game made a movie. It's cops vs. drug dealers in a building, and each floor the difficulty is increased. The plot is simple, yes, but for the sake of the film, it really doesn't need to be much complicated. My only complaint with the movie is sometimes they try too hard to make the characters deeper, showing some of their past and misfortunes, but all it does is stall the movie. But The Raid has some of the best action sequences I have ever seen, it is brilliantly choreographed and some of the camera-work is pretty good. Excellent action flick!

Move over John Woo, the mantle of top action film director has been passed to Gareth Evans. This is the most stunning and exciting action film I have seen in forever and a day. This reminded me of being ten years-old and watching Kung Fu Theater, showing on a UHF station on and old black and white TV. If you are a fan of action movies go and see this film right now.Indubitably, this is like a shot of adrenalin straight to the heart of the action film genre. I plan on checking out the other two films in director Evans' filmography, Merantau and Footsteps.check out our full review at 3guys1movie.com

Review title: This is Gareth Evans' furiously paced, martial arts masterpiece.
Review_body: When a SWAT team enters a 30-storey apartment block looking to kill a notorious crime lord, they don't realise the danger lying in wait. What seems like a routine mission on paper is anything but as it becomes increasingly apparent that the real problem is surviving long enough to get back out again.The story may seem rudimentary, but it in its brief runtime it manages to input more than enough character development to keep things from becoming stale. But... this film hasn't been designed to tell a compelling story. It's a setup for some of the most exciting and creative action sequences ever put to film, all set to the throbbing pulse of its sound design.'The Raid' is a breathtaking display of martial arts choreography; a constant sensory assault of bloodthirsty mayhem, with each floor rigged to explode into frenetic action. And Gareth Evans is well aware how to expertly stage these sequences by letting the camera linger on the fight scenes. There's no obtrusive close-ups, no rapid edits, just plenty of extended shots to showcase the talent of the individuals and their fighting techniques on camera.The violent criminals think they have things covered, but what they don't count on is Rama (Iko Uwais) not only fighting back, but messing everyone up in style. Whether using his bare hands to batter his opponents, or using the environment to bone-crunching effect, he demonstrates a skillset few people have. He's a hero worth rooting for as he turns the tables on his attackers (sometimes literally) and forges a bloody path to the top of the high-rise.Unrelenting and unforgettable, writer/director/editor Gareth Evans has taken a simple premise, executed it with flair, and turned out a masterful, memorable action thriller.

I saw The Raid by accident. The details of how that came to be don't matter: this is simply not a genre I seek out, but one day found myself in the cinema watching on the big screen. What a treat. Just the right hint of comedy and tension. The kinetic energy of the fight scenes is a visceral thrill. The lead actor is hugely charismatic, and the subversion of the genre in the end, the fact that it is the good guys who double-up on the bad guy and and not the other way round, was gleefully transgressive. I recently sought it out on DVD and enjoyed it on the small screen all over again. The audience I saw it with in the cinema are hard-core fans of this type of movie, and they lapped it up. It clearly has broad appeal. Recommended to audiences young, old, and skeptical.

Review title: The most satisfying action film in years!
Review_body: After hearing so much about The Raid, I knew I had to see it. I am a sucker for foreign action flicks, particularly Asian action, and The Raid is one of the best I've seen in a long, long time. My usual complaints about action films generally stem from a lack of action to satisfy and a lack of diversity in the action presented. Not here. The Raid is so filled with action and is creative enough with it, that any action buff will be satisfied with what is presented.The Raid is simple enough: a special forces team is sent into a derelict apartment housing filled with criminal dwellers. However, the mission goes wrong and it's a fight for survival as the remaining team fights through the floors to reach the top and take out their main target. There is little downtime in this film. With a few expositionary scenes, the majority of the film is dedicated to ass kicking. And ass kicking it does plenty of. Everything an action junkie could want is here. From gun fights to one on one combat to two on one combat, there is no shortage of adrenaline here. And the action is all brutal, with no wire-fu or special effects seen here. It's all bone-crunching, throat slicing, body beating realism.Thankfully the fights are not only varied, with few of them seeming repetitive or boring, and they are all shown with great precision.
